DEBATE.TITLE: STUDENT AND YOUTH ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT (BUDGET MEASURES) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 25 October.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill will amend the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 to implement budget decisions relating to student assistance. The measures will focus the financial help provided by the taxpayer more sharply on those students most in need and improve services to clients and their families.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Austudy and permanent residents who choose not to become Australian citizens

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the Austudy program is to assist financially disadvantaged students who are Australian citizens or permanent residents to complete secondary education and gain an initial tertiary qualification.

While substantial, the funds available for Austudy are limited and priorities for their expenditure must be set within overall budgetary constraints. The bill will amend the act so that, from 1 January 1996, Austudy will be targeted to students who have a long-term commitment to contributing to the Australian community and who show their commitment by becoming Australian citizens. The decision to take out Australian citizenship will remain a matter of individual choice.

In the usual case, a student who is a permanent resident of Australia will be able to receive Austudy until he or she meets the residency requirement for Australian citizenship, which is normally two years after the person is granted permanent resident status and for one additional year. To be eligible to continue receiving Austudy after that year, the person must, before the end of that year, apply for Australian citizenship and have that application approved by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Students whose applications are approved within the required time frame, if otherwise eligible, will continue to receive Austudy while they are waiting to attend a citizenship conferral ceremony.

As people may not apply for citizenship in their own right until they are 16 years old, students who have met the residency requirement before they turn 16 will have one year from their 16th birthday to become, or obtain approval to become, an Australian citizen, during which time they may be eligible for Austudy. The basic student payment for 16- and 17-year-olds will be available to permanent residents.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Consolidation of income support for secondary students aged 16 and 17

PARA.TAB: To continue the process of streamlining government assistance to families, all payments to 16- and 17-year-old secondary students will be administered through the Department of Employment, Education and Training from 1 July 1996. The basic family payment currently paid for 16- and 17-year-old secondary students by the Department of Social Security will be replaced by a payment known as the basic student payment.

This will remove the inconvenience of families having to deal with both the Department of Social Security for family payment and the Department of Employment, Education and Training for Austudy to establish eligibility for benefits for older student children. It also reflects the government's intention that assistance to young people in this age group is conditional on their participation in education or training.

The basic student payment will be means tested on the student's income and the income of his or her parent or parents. There will also be a family assets test. The income and assets tests thresholds will be similar to those currently applying to the basic family payment.

The basic student payment will be a maximum of $500 a year. It will be paid in two instalments of $250 maximum. In most cases these payments will be made in January and July of the year of study to the student's nominated parent or approved care organisation.

Arrangements will be put in place for students who, on 30 June 1996, are 16 or 17 and eligible for the basic family payment to transfer to the basic student payment on 1 July 1996. Students who turn 16 on or after 1 July 1996 and who have been eligible for the basic family payment immediately before they turn 16 will transfer to the basic student payment on their 16th birthday.
The bill includes a number of consequential amendments to the Social Security Act 1991 to abolish family payment for children 16 years and over.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Changes to the Austudy/Abstudy supplement scheme

PARA.TAB: The Austudy/Abstudy supplement scheme is a loan scheme under which tertiary students can forgo part or all of their Austudy or Abstudy benefits, up to a maximum of $3,500 a year, for an interest-free loan of twice the amount of benefits forgone, that is, up to $7,000 a year.

Students who have already received Austudy or Abstudy at the time of application may maximise the amount of supplement they are able to receive by forgoing some or all of those benefits previously paid. However, under the existing arrangements this must be done by specified cut-off dates of 31 May, for benefits received during the period from 1 January to 31 May, or 30 September, for benefits received during the period from 1 July to 30 September.

This bill proposes to abolish these cut-off dates so that students can trade Austudy or Abstudy benefits at any time before the end of their eligibility period. The student, therefore, will be able to take the maximum amount of supplement to which he or she is entitled at a time of their own choosing. This will mean that a student who applies late in the eligibility period will be able to obtain a greater amount of supplement than under the existing arrangements. The amendments will take effect from 1 January 1996.

Supplement loans are also available to a second category of students. Dependent tertiary students who meet all the criteria for Austudy or Abstudy apart from the parental income test are able to obtain a loan of up to $2,000 a year if their parents' adjusted income is under $50,850. Only a small number of students have chosen to take up this option. The government has decided, therefore, that, from 1 January 1996, loans for students from families with parental income above the Austudy or Abstudy limits will no longer be available. This is consistent with the government's commitment to target assistance to those in greatest need. The bill includes amendments to give effect to this decision. Students from low income families who are eligible for Austudy or Abstudy will not be affected by this change. These students will continue to have access to supplement loans of up to $7,000 a year.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Penalty for failure to notify a change in circumstances

PARA.TAB: Currently a person who is in receipt of benefits under the act is obliged to tell the department, within seven days of their occurrence, of certain events that may affect the level of benefit being paid. In some circumstances, a failure to do so could lead to a person being imprisoned for up to 12 months. The government has decided to increase the amount of time a person has to tell the department of such events from seven to 14 days. It has also decided to remove the criminal offence.

However, it still remains important that the department becomes aware of changes in the circumstances of a person receiving a benefit, because it could mean that a person is receiving more benefit than the legal entitlement. Therefore, in place of the criminal sanction, the bill inserts a provision that makes a person liable for a penalty of $10 for each week, or part of a week, up to a maximum of $1,000 where a person fails to inform the department within 14 days of an event which affects eligibility. Failure to notify changes in circumstances is now the most significant factor contributing to the size of student assistance debt. It is hoped that this change will encourage the earlier reporting of changes and will ultimately reduce the level of student indebtedness.

The bill includes an amendment to omit reference to the Austudy and Abstudy dependent spouse allowance—DSA—which is necessary because of the government's decision to abolish this allowance. From 1 January 1996, clients in respect of whom the DSA would have been payable will be able to apply for the parenting allowance provided by the Department of Social Security.
The bill also proposes a number of other minor amendments to the act. These are explained in this bill's explanatory memorandum.

Overall, these measures build on progressive improvements to Austudy client services in recent years to reinforce the government's commitment to assist students in greatest need. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I noted the concluding remark of the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) that the government has got additional amendments to this legislation. I must say that I am not aware of these amendments and I do not know whether they have been circulated to the opposition. When were they sent to Senator Hill?
—Senator Hill has been briefed on it.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Order! My understanding is that they were circulated yesterday afternoon.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly not aware of these amendments. It is, I have to say for the record, all too typical of the legislation that has come through from this department that a bill is no sooner introduced than it is amended. You get the impression that this is a government which is simply trying to think on the run in putting forward legislation. It knew that there was a possibility of an election towards the end of this year, which the govenment has now backed away from; yet it has rushed legislation in without, once again, thinking it through. Of course, the monumental example of the unthought-through government measure was Working Nation, which took something like a year to invent after the initial announcements were made without any of the supporting detail for it.

PARA.TAB: We have now got what one would suppose would normally be a straightforward piece of legislation coming before the parliament, and before it is even here it is amended. This is a government that seems unable to undertake even the simplest of tasks without making a welter of them. Of course, it means that, because it cannot get its own act together, it is unable to provide the opposition with adequate courtesies in terms of the handling and treatment of this legislation. I do not consider it at all satisfactory that amendments should be made available to the opposition, as I understand from the government that they have been, only hours before the bill is introduced into the parliament. It is quite unsatisfactory that quite substantial amendments—as I see from the sheets of paper that have just been presented to me—are now to be made to the legislation without the opposition having had adequate time to consider them.

This legislation amends the Student Assistance Act 1973 to make changes to Austudy which were foreshadowed in the May budget. The bill contains two significant amendments and a number of minor changes. The changes having been foreshadowed in the budget, one would have thought that this legislation could have been brought before the parliament considerably earlier than November; there has been an extraordinary timelag in the bringing forward of this piece of legislation. It has now been brought forward at the death knock of this year's parliamentary sittings, and, even now, the government cannot get it right.

The legislation proposes to replace family payments for 16- and 17-year-old secondary students with a new student payment, and to restrict entitlement to Austudy to Australian citizens. Some other amendments relate to the elimination of Austudy category 2 loans, changes to category 1 loans, the imposition of a fine for failure to notify change of circumstance, and the removal of the dependent spouse rebate.

The major changes to the bill are contained in schedules 3, 5 and 6. Schedule 3 of the bill restricts Austudy to Australian citizens. In 1994, approximately 47,000 permanent residents received Austudy benefits. Letters have been sent to such people by DEET, informing them of the requirement for them to become citizens to remain eligible for Austudy. This measure has been presented by the government as a tighter targeting measure which will prevent rorting of the system.

The schedule mirrors an amendment to HECS, the higher education contribution scheme. In relation to that amendment, the coalition foreshadowed an amendment which would restrict the government's proposals to persons who would take out permanent residency and commence studies from 1 January 1996. HECS is different from Austudy in that it is a loan, while Austudy is a direct payment involving considerable moneys and ought, in the first instance, to be directed to Australian citizens. The restriction of Austudy to Australian citizens is expected to provide savings of $10.34 million in 1995-96, $19.93 million in 1996-97, $20.65 million in 1997-98 and $21.43 million in 1998-99.

Schedules 5 and 6 are related amendments. Schedule 6 abolishes family payment for any person over 16 years of age. Schedule 5 establishes a new basic student payment. These amendments represent a shift in the philosophical justification for financial assistance to 16-year-olds and over. The justification for schedules 5 and 6 is that any financial assistance for children 16 years and over ought to be targeted to support their engagement in full-time study or training.

The assumption underlying this has to be questioned. The government's blithe assumption that, somehow or other, anyone receiving assistance who is over the age of 16 years is going to be engaged in full-time study or training is not an accurate one. Whatever the government may desire to be the case, that is not an accurate assumption. There are many young people in that position who wish to be in employment—either full-time employment in the workplace or part-time employment.

The net effect of these amendments is that families will be worse off. We have heard a great deal of noise from this government about how much it cares for families and looks after those families most in need. What we have before us is yet another piece of evidence of the disregard of the interests of Australian families, particularly those who are most disadvantaged. It is clear that this legislation is something of an embarrassment to the government. The minister has come in here to read a speech which the department has prepared for him and which he has delivered in his usual impassioned style. But no-one else from the government is around to clearly support and argue for this piece of legislation, lest they be seen, I suppose, to participate in this further damage done to Australian families, because the net effect of the legislation, as I have said, is that families will be worse off.

The current family payment is more generous than the proposed student payment, and the means test which is being imposed on this benefit is more stringent than that which used to apply to the family payment. The new student payment, as I understand it, will consist of a lump sum payment of $500 per year to be paid in two instalments. There will be no graduation of the student payment according to the level of income. Persons on low incomes will be able to apply for Austudy in addition to the basic student payment.

The current family payment is $564 a year—$64 more than proposed for this payment. Families at present who are on low incomes can apply for either Austudy or additional family payment. The means test for the new basic student payment at this stage seems to be more stringent than that which applies to family payment. Eligibility for student payment will be subject to `means testing arrangements that are similar to Austudy'—those are the words that are used. The exact details of the means test are yet to be defined. As seems more and more usual under Labor, we are debating legislation with dubious substance, the details of which are yet to be determined. And, as we have seen, the government still has further details to put before us which it has just thought of.

The current family payment assets test threshold is $584,500. Under Austudy the assets test threshold is $393,750. In addition, the family payment test has hardship provisions which allow for circumstances where families have high asset value but no or low income. Austudy has no such provisions. This has been the cause of constant complaints from rural communities that, despite low income, their asset value excludes them from being eligible for Austudy. The replacement of the family payment system with student payment is estimated to provide savings of $19.69 million in 1996-97, $19.21 million in 1997-98 and $19.03 million in 1998-99.

The government argues that these new measures are advantageous in that families no longer need to deal with both DEET and the Department of Social Security, but will now fall under the umbrella of DEET alone. Whether families will welcome falling under the Department of Employment, Education and Training is a significant question that families may like to ask themselves when they look at the consequences of the policies pursued by this department, and its horrendous size. Being under this department could be quite a crushing burden for many families to carry.

The other changes which the bill makes are relatively minor. Schedule 1 relates to category 1 loans. These loans enable students on Austudy to trade in part of their payment for a loan double the amount traded. This schedule removes the possibility of combining broken periods of eligibility in applying for the loan, but enables students to take up a loan at any time of the year. It also removes the cut-off date for repayment of such loans. This last amendment is expected to provide savings of $6 million.

Schedule 2 of the legislation abolishes Austudy category 2 loans. These loans are for students who would be eligible for Austudy payments but are excluded by the means test. Such students could take out interest free loans of up to $2,000. The government has decided to do away with these loans, as the demand for them was not as great as expected. Apparently, only about 4,000 to 5,000 students took up this option, although the department estimated that some 11,000 to 15,000 students would avail themselves of these loans.

There is an important question to be asked about the nature of the students who took out these loans. My recollection is that this measure was introduced to be of specific benefit to rural students. Indeed, it was recommended by the Chapman inquiry that loans be made more freely available so that students who might be eligible for Austudy payments but for the assets tests could avail themselves of loans.

I think it would be valuable for the government to provide information as to whether or not the 4,000 to 5,000 students who took out these loans were distinctively rural students. Indeed, that raises the question of whether or not the abolition of these loans will be of particular disadvantage to rural students. If that is so, this will be just another example of rural Australia and farming families struggling to make a go of it under the mismanagement of the country—another blow to these families.

The government says that this measure will provide savings, which will be only $760,000 in 1995-96, $2.7 million in 1996-97, and $3.13 million in 1997-98. There is a question about this measure and I would appreciate it if the minister, in his response, could provide to the parliament some information about the nature of the students who will be excluded from loans by this particular savings measure.

I must say that I do find it a quite extraordinary justification for cutting out a measure that fewer have used it than the department anticipated. Presumably, it was of great value to these 4,000 to 5,000 students—not an inconsiderable number. They needed these loans—and they were only loans. It is not as if the government has been hit with expenditure in this area that was much greater than expected. It is not as if we are facing a major blow-out here. In fact, the expenditures are not great and, presumably, the measure was of value to these students.

Schedule 4 of the bill abolishes the Austudy and Abstudy dependent spouse allowances. Spouses will be able to apply for the parenting allowance which commenced in July this year. This particular change has no financial implications.

Schedule 7 imposes a $10 weekly fine for failing to notify the department of a change in circumstances which may affect eligibility for Austudy. It is anticipated that this measure will generate revenue of $3 million in 1996-97, and another $2.5 million in identification of overpayments.

Schedule 8 clarifies the application of the parental income test in the case of persons in state or foster care. Schedule 9 of the bill gives the secretary greater discretion in negotiating the collection of debt.

As we all remember, 1994 was the International Year of the Family. The silence coming from the government in relation to this year has been deafening. It seems that we have, in this legislation, further evidence that the government does not have families clearly in its focus, because it is restricting eligibility for family payments and actually reducing access to assistance for families who need it.

The government's record on families is, of course, nothing whatever to be proud of. It is families which have borne the brunt of the `recession that we had to have' of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). It is families which are suffering as unemployment creeps up. We now have something like 780,000 unemployed people in Australia. A great many of them have families to support.

We see the failure of the government's promise to provide sustainable employment growth. We see unemployment creeping up. We see long-term unemployment creeping up. It is now higher than it was eight months ago. Working Nation is supposed to be in operation fully now, yet we find youth unemployment 29 per cent higher than it was when Working Nation was introduced. We have the most appalling performance from this government on a matter which is of fundamental importance to families. We see in this legislation yet another blow to those struggling families in terms of the income that they will be receiving.

The International Year of the Family report from the National Council for the International Year of the Family is a comprehensive report which seems to have largely sunk without trace. I suppose one has to reflect on why this is so and part of the answer may be the character of the two ministers who are responsible for family services in this government.

The senior minister, the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) has just been found to have lied to a royal commission and I suppose she has been somewhat preoccupied with trying to stay in her place. It is a fight which she is probably losing despite the bravado we are seeing at the present time. Frankly, the government cannot sustain the continued presence on the front bench of this minister, who now has no public credibility whatsoever. Her presence there is of deep concern to many people who sit on the front bench and to many who sit behind her as well. So much for the senior minister.

The junior minister, the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), is somebody who thinks it is a major initiative to recommend that men be issued with maps in supermarkets. She is a person whose preoccupations are clearly completely misguided and who slips easily and readily into sexist language despite all the ideological rhetoric which pours from her in the Senate.

They are scarcely a dynamic duo to be looking after Australia's families. Line them up with the Prime Minister, who is busy advising the Japanese how they should build their cities while young people are homeless and roaming the streets of Australian cities. The Keating government should be ashamed of its disregard for Australian families. I do not think anybody, when they look at the record of this government, could believe for a moment that they have had the interests of Australian families at heart, or the interests of the young people of those families. If they had then we would not now be facing these appalling conditions where, as I have said, youth unemployment is higher than it was when Working Nation came down.

We have tens of thousands of homeless young people roaming the streets of Australian cities. They are trying to get some effective assistance to become, once more, full participating members of this society. We have the highest rate of youth suicide in the world, and unemployment is clearly a very significant contributor to that, especially for young people in rural areas. Here we see the government bringing before this parliament a piece of legislation which makes a virtue of the fact that it is cutting out educational loans to these young people. This is a government which has betrayed a generation of Australians. Out there that is well known, and nowhere is it more clearly realised than amongst young unemployed people.

I attended in August a conference in Adelaide entitled `Jobs for young Australians'. Before I had even delivered any remarks at that conference I was besieged by young people saying, `What we want, please, are real jobs. We are sick of being recycled through the training schemes of the Department of Employment, Education and Training which do not lead on to real jobs. We are sick of being used as fodder to pad out the statistics and make it appear as though the government is addressing these problems when it is not.'

This is a government which has lost its way, which has lost its sense of priorities. It is a government which has a lot of rhetoric about how it is helping young people through the youth training initiative, the youth training allowance, the national training wage—all these initiatives which are supposed to be helping young people. And what is the reality? The reality is that we have the lowest number of young people in apprenticeships and traineeships as a proportion of the work force for three decades. What an abysmal failure. Why has this come about? Why has there been this loss of focus, why has there been this betrayal of young Australians? It is because the government has not had its eye fixed on the ball. It has had its eye fixed on one priority only, and that is how it can preserve the interests of its mates in the ACTU.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's all it thinks about.

—That is the only thing that it thinks about, as the member for Mitchell has said. This has been the preoccupation of this government, and we have seen this again in the government's failure to condemn the strikes that have besieged this nation in recent weeks: the blockade of Western Australia, the attack on CRA's employees who have dared to enter into individual contracts with their employer, supposedly something the government encouraged but something never really accepted by the mates in the ACTU. We have now seen the stumbling and the twisting by the government as this strike has taken place, and it has occurred for one reason and one reason only.
—You've got seven minutes left.

—You want these people to be out there supporting you during the election campaign, don't you? I wonder if the member for Moreton has members of one of the major unions working in his office now. Perhaps the member for Moreton can tell this House how many union members are already detailed to help him try to get re-election in Moreton, because he is unknown in that electorate. He is not interested in helping unemployed people; he is a member of the Left, so he is interested in these big international issues. The unemployed kids and the homeless kids in Moreton in Brisbane may be concerned about nuclear testing, as most Australians are, but, believe me, they are much more concerned about jobs. They are concerned about getting a home; they are concerned about participating in Australian society. If you go to Moreton they will ask you, `Who's the member here?' They have never heard of Garrie Gibson, because he is so busy promoting the ideological and international concerns of the Left. He is one of the people who betrayed this generation.

PARA.TAB: The member for Moreton is about to get a hefty rebuff, a hefty kick in the backside, from the electors of Moreton when the election is called, and he knows it. Let him get up and defend this piece of legislation. Let him tell people in this parliament how much this government is doing for young people, and then let him go out and talk to them and see whether they believe it or not. They do not believe it. They believe they have been betrayed, and no amount of bureaucracy, no amount of shuffling these payments, as this legislation does, from one department to another, no amount of saying to these young people, `I'm from DEET and I'm here to help you' is going to convince them. What they want is what this government has been unable to deliver. It has been an appalling performance and I am afraid this unthought-out, yet to be further amended piece of legislation which has been thrown into the parliament in its dying days is not going to convince anyone that this government has got any concern for Australian families or for young people.

TALK.START.PARA: —The shadow minister for employment, training and family services, the member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) has very well stated the general backdrop to training and unemployment and the various issues. The Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Budget Measures) Bill is a budget measure, and I want to touch on some of those government decisions over the last three years which impact on students. All governments like to be the bearers of good news and the irony of this, of course, is that there are some budget savings. We have heard about the loan withdrawal, et cetera.

PARA.TAB: Let us think about the tax increase and impact on the cost of living for students: wholesale sales tax on food, rent, repairs, clothes, the whole lot. In one bound, the government puts great hurdles in front of young people struggling with their increasing costs. In regional areas, there is fuel excise, that wonderful tax gatherer that the government has used over the decade or more—up to $10 billion it now collects. It impacts drastically on the cost of education for every young person. Whether they are trying to catch the bus every three or four months to spend time back with their families, or whether they are catching a bus to the university, whatever it is, these costs impact on the students of Australia. Of course, we will not talk about, in this discussion, the HECS contribution and the attempts at increasing that.

I will quickly touch on interest rates. In a variety of ways, interest rates impact on every aspect of Australian life. The other day I had one example pointed out to me by a state member, on state debt, which I think is worth noting. In the 1980s the state government of South Australia was paying something like $150 million on its outstanding state debt. During the 1990s, for a variety of factors we will not dwell on here, it went to a bit under $750 million. So there we have $500 million or $600 million dollars just in interest payments that that particular state is liable for.

Whilst all this discussion goes on about the role of the state and its contribution to the welfare of students—and no doubt it will come up at the federal election—the reality for the state of South Australia was that, with those three interest rate rises of last year, despite all the struggling to balance the books, or at least trying to balance the books, that $80 million or $90 million they tried to trim off to get to some balance was wiped out in one hit by those interest rate rises. That has an impact on the ability to develop facilities, to offer allowances and to allocate extra places in the universities.

I come to inflation. Inflation is on the march again in this country for a variety of reasons. That in itself just makes the hurdles in front of students that much more difficult. It has been said many times that all that the overwhelming majority of students wants to aim for is permanent and stable employment. In an earlier discussion I touched on the issue of regional Australia, where it is just that much harder and that much more difficult. I will not revisit that.

In my brief contribution this morning I say to the government: please acknowledge, at the very least, the impact that these increases in taxation, increases in costs, whatever they might be, do have on the students of Australia. We cannot continue to delude ourselves that they are just incidentals and off to the side—some sideshow in the general life of the nation. I now touch on a little inequity that people have brought to my attention in recent days in relation to the formal training allowance. There is a group between the ages of 18 and 21 that has the same costs, and increasing costs, because of the economic policies of this government. Those who are doing a CES approved course are denied $30 per week. They are denied $30 per week if they are doing a full-time course and $20 per week for a part-time course.

That makes the difference for these young people to at least survive with a little bit of dignity. It is just another anomaly in the programs of the government. I appeal to the government to acknowledge these extra costs that are put on students and to acknowledge that, every time you take something away from them at the same time as you add a cost to them, you are making it just that much more difficult for them to contribute and to become citizens who can live with dignity and a positive approach which this nation will benefit from.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not keep honourable members long, but I need to make some remarks about the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Budget Measures) Bill 1995, because I object to the philosophical approach of the government in taking family payments out of the hands of families and directing them straight to students.
—That is wrong.
—You are not doing that? That is not your intention?
—Senator Harradine has been reassured on that point.

—Fine. I am pleased to hear that, because it was a great concern of mine. In the original statements of the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) and in the way in which this matter first came to the notice of the House, it appeared that the government was taking the step of putting 16- and 17-year-olds into a relationship with the government as its direct mendicants; and I am delighted to hear the minister say that that is not going to occur. I notice that the provisions of the explanatory memorandum allow for those additional family payments to continue where there are larger families, and we also have the incremental arrangement for families with more than three children, as the explanatory memorandum sets out. I thank the minister for the clarification. I am delighted to hear it.

PARA.TAB: I will confine my remarks to the citizenship provisions, which I think are a valid step for the government to take. Benefits in many areas should be confined to those people who are Australian citizens. I note that it is the government's intention, with regard to the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Budget Measures) Bill 1995, to provide for students who are permanent residents to receive Austudy until they achieve the age of eligibility or the period of residency that will entitle them to seek Australian citizenship, which is normally two years after the person has been granted permanent resident status.

The guarantees requested of migrant families—barring refugees—are such that, in most instances, there is no need for this provision. Families migrating to Australia should be prepared to carry the cost of education for their offspring until their students reach that entitlement status of two years residency and thus become eligible for Australian citizenship. I see no reason why the Australian community needs to further extend its largess to permanent residents who are waiting to receive citizenship. I see no anomalies there. There will be circumstances where a special benefit is needed, in cases of refugees or other people suffering hardship, and I am sure that the act could make allowances for that. I commend the government on this step, which is a wise one, and the minister's assurance concerning families is pleasing.

I do note, however, a cheese-paring attitude in cutting payments down, thus saving $19 million per year for the first three years of this process. If any area of the Australian community needs support, it is Australian families. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) makes nice statements about having `family television'. That is no sop. That indefinite, pie in the sky promise of a family television station—`It will never happen; let's give it to Murdoch!'—is no substitute for support of the families of western Sydney, western Melbourne or anywhere else. Minister Free is shaking his head, but he can sun himself in the middle of the Pacific, basking in the spotlight of international television and—

TALK.START.PARA: —And radio!
—Ah! You did not get there. What a pity! I know you were there in spirit, because you had that great petition.

PARA.TAB: A greater commitment for Australian families is needed. The International Year of the Family has passed and the government has left us with the impression that to live in a family is to live dangerously, because that is where people get bashed. However, the facts and the statistics are completely the opposite. One of the safest places to live is in a fully committed family and that is where children and young people are likely to survive and survive well.

I thank the minister for clarifying the difficulties that have arisen in regard to schedules 5 and 6. I request that the government focus more strongly on its family policies. The minister at the table ought to be doing that. He knows what the problems are. He ought to be able to override people such as Minister Crowley. He ought to be able to override the lady who has already announced a suicide task force twice or three times. Nothing has happened. The minister ought to be able to put pressure on, and we would appreciate it if he did.

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank those honourable members who participated in the debate. I address some of the remarks that have been made. I want to begin, though, by assuring the Committee that the basic student payment does have the interests of young people at heart. It will clarify service delivery arrangements for 16-year-olds and 17-year-olds. It has been admitted that, for some time, there has been confusion about whether the Department of Social Security or the Department of Employment, Education and Training should be the organisation to help these clients. Indeed, the opposition itself—Senator Tierney in the Senate in his committee report on Austudy—expressed concern about this very matter, about the need to get streamlined service to these clients in the face of apparent gaps between what happens in the Department of Employment, Education and Training on one hand and in the Department of Social Security on the other.

PARA.TAB: The government believes that the integration of all support for 16-year-olds and 17-year-olds within DEET will help. If they are studying, they have available assistance through Austudy, Abstudy or now the basic student payment. If those 16-year-olds and 17-year-olds happen to be seeking work, assistance is available through the youth training initiative, again within the one department. The government believes that it is appropriate to locate services to all 16-year-olds and 17-year-olds in that one department because it also reinforces the expectations of the community and the government that young people should be supported actively to develop themselves through education and training or active jobsearch and not to stay passively on Department of Social Security welfare benefit.

I was pleased to hear the opposition's concern for young homeless people. A key element of the government's amendments to this bill is that they are explicitly intended to provide special support and protection for recipients of the Austudy student homeless rate.

The honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) raised four questions which I will attempt to address in this response. The basic student payment, he said, is less generous than the basic family payment—$500 against $564. That is true, but I would point out to him that the new arrangements for the timing of the payments provide a much more sensible arrangement for assisting students, providing payments, as they do, at the beginning of each semester in the year of study.

Secondly, I turn to his assertion that the assets and income test for basic student payment is more stringent than for basic family payment. For a start, I turn to the income test. Farming and business families will be better off under the basic student payment assets test, but I will come to that in a moment.

The threshold for the personal income test will be similar to the current basic family payment and Austudy threshold of $6,000. However, the threshold for the parental income test will be similar to the basic family payment threshold, which will be $61,020 in 1996. That approach—I am sure the honourable member for Goldstein will agree—will ensure that higher income families will also receive assistance for their student children. The assets test will be similar to the assets test applying under Austudy. The family assets test, not including the family home, will be $393,750 next year—and that is less than the threshold applying under the basic family payment, which is $559,250.

But the honourable member for Goldstein should remember that a 50 per cent discount applies to the value of business and farm interests owned and operated by one or more assessable family members. And when one applies the 50 per cent discount, remember it is to net assets excluding the home or, in the case of a farm, the homestead and curtilage. So it is net assets, free of debt, with a 50 per cent discount applied. That means that the assets threshold, say, for a farming family would be $787,500, which I think is slightly above the average farm value. Certainly, from data relating to success rates of Austudy applicants from rural areas as opposed to urban areas, there is little or no difference.

On the fourth matter that the honourable member for Goldstein raised, the matter of category 2 loans, I am afraid I do not have the information available to me about the geographical location of those people in receipt of category 2 loans. But if he was attempting to make the case that, somehow or other, students from income-poor rural families would be excluded from loans because of the abolition of category 2, I should make the point to him that category 2 loans are available for the relatively better off students. They are available to students from families where the adjusted family income is just over $50,000. I think he has difficulty making out a case that we are affecting students from income-poor rural families.

In the broad, it is all part of the government's effort to tightly target student assistance to those students in greatest need. Remember, it is a big program; it involves spending of about $1.7 billion this year assisting over half a million students. We need to make sure that those benefits get to students who need them most.

The final point I will address is the honourable member for Goldstein's claim that youth unemployment now is actually higher than it was when Working Nation was introduced. I heard him say it last evening and he said it again today. On neither occasion has he given the committee the benefit of any figures. If I can help him with figures, the seasonally adjusted financial year average for teenage unemployment—the 15- to 19-year-olds—in 1993-94, which was the year that Working Nation was introduced, was 110,000. In 1994-95 it was 94,000—a drop of some 16,000. The rate of unemployment among those teenagers in the work force fell from 32.3 to 27.7 per cent and the rate of teenage unemployment as a proportion of the age group fell from 8.6 to 7.4 per cent over the period. As I say, I would be obliged if the honourable member for Goldstein would present the figures at some stage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Administrator recommending appropriation announced.
Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

`(3) Subject to subsection (4), if:
(a)an amount of benefit under this Part would, apart from this section, be payable to the person in respect of a period; and

SPEECH.PARA: `(5) The Court, Minister or Department referred to in subparagraphs (1)(c)(i) and (ii) can be from the Commonwealth or a State or Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: `7C. For the purposes of sections 7A and 7B, the residency requirements for a person on a particular day, whether before or after the commencement of this section, are that the person:

SPEECH.PARA: `7D. Sections 7A and 7B do not have any effect in relation to:
