in respect of a year that is before the year 1996.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: The Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Budget Measures) Bill 1995 seeks to amend the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 by, amongst other things, modifying the eligibility provisions for the Austudy scheme for certain permanent residents. These amendments clarify when those provisions apply. The bill currently refers to the day a permanent resident student first satisfied the residency requirements and provides that, if that day is more than 12 months past, the person is ineligible to get Austudy even if he or she does not currently satisfy the residency requirements. These amendments will clarify that the person who does not currently satisfy the residency requirements will not be affected by the change.

PARA.TAB: The amendments also introduce slightly different rules for permanent resident students who are not yet 19 years of age and who are eligible for the independent rate of Austudy because they are orphans or because their parents cannot exercise normal parenting responsibilities, or they are unable to live at home with their parents because of exceptional circumstances, or they are refugees, or they are in state approved care arrangements. Permanent residents in one of these groups will be able to get Austudy until they turn 19. This is because they cannot apply for citizenship in their own right until they are 18 and they then have one year in which to become Australian citizens. Once these students turn 19 they will, like all other Austudy recipients, be ineligible for Austudy after a particular day if on that day they satisfy the residency requirements but they have not continuously satisfied them for at least 12 months, and have not been approved for citizenship.

I have presented the explanatory memorandum to the bill, and as the committee can see these amendments are minor. They are beneficial to clients in that they extend protection to those in the student homeless category and they clarify the application to those currently eligible. On the process and the matter raised by the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) earlier in this debate, I can assure the honourable member that there was no discourtesy intended towards the opposition. The amendments were circulated yesterday as soon as caucus approval was obtained for them. I am also informed that Senator Hill's office was briefed fully on the amendments on Monday. While I am sorry that the honourable member for Goldstein was not fully briefed this morning, perhaps it is a matter he might care to take up with Leader of the Opposition in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments, I believe, were provided to Senator Hill's office late yesterday. I am interested in the comments that there was a briefing about them on Monday. As far as I am aware, the shadow minister was not clearly aware of the details of these amendments until yesterday. Indeed, they seem to have come through so late that there was little time to look at them. Certainly the first time that I viewed these amendments was when they were presented in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: As the minister said, the amendments appear to be relatively minor. However, we have not had time to study them and frankly I do not believe that Senator Hill's office has had a full briefing on these amendments. I have been in contact with them in the course of this debate and I have been unable to get from them any view of that kind. I am not sure how the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Mr Free) is able to say that there has been a full briefing.

If the department is under the impression that a briefing was given, it does not seem to have been a terribly satisfactory briefing because Senator Hill's office does not appear to be clearly aware that they had been informed of these amendments before yesterday. We just have to leave the matter as it stands there, and that is unfortunate. It is not a major issue in terms of the substance of these amendments but it is a matter of process and I register a protest about it. Too often we have had legislation brought forward for the education and training area to which the government has sought to introduce amendments after the legislation has come into the House.

There has been ample time to prepare this legislation. As the minister said, it was foreshadowed in the May budget and it is now November. Apparently, the government is still having second thoughts about the legislation. This is not a satisfactory matter and it highlights the inability of the government to get its act together in terms of the preparation of its legislative program. I note that fact, and I am sure that the people of Australia will note that the government seems to be in a continuing state of confusion on these matters. I reserve any final endorsement of these amendments. We will not oppose them here, and I am sure that the Senate will look at them closely and assure itself that they are satisfactory.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—The question is that this bill, as amended, be reported to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIME MINISTER AND CABINET (MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 20 November.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns The Hon G.T.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHNS
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State, Assistant Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Prime Minister and Cabinet (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill is to amend the Economic Planning Advisory Council Act 1983, the Parliamentary Allowances Act 1952, the Parliamentary Presiding Officers Act 1965 and the Public Service Act 1922. Details of the various amendments are set out in the explanatory memorandum which accompanies the bill.

PARA.TAB: The bill implements the decision of the government which was announced in August 1994 to abolish the Economic Planning Advisory Council, the council, and establish in its place an Economic Planning Advisory Commission, the commission.

When the government established the council in 1983, there was a clear need to improve consultation among business, trade unions, community groups and government, on economic issues. Over the past decade, EPAC has contributed substantially to promoting a broader understanding of Australia's medium- and long-term economic and social prospects and consultation is now much more widespread than in the early 1980s. The need for a body like the council has diminished accordingly.

The government now intends to build on the council's achievements by establishing the new commission. The new commission will assume the role of the office of EPAC rather than that of the council itself. Its public information role will be expanded and its new functions will allow it to focus more directly on the provision of advice to government on medium- to long-term social and economic issues. The commission will also have an expanded capacity to undertake special projects, such as the major national strategies conference `Shaping our future' held in November 1994, and to undertake task force work on particular issues.

The amendments to the Public Service Act will achieve two aims. As honourable members are aware, the annual reports of Commonwealth departments and budget funded agencies are a most important element in the overall accountability process. The Public Service Act requires annual reports to be prepared in accordance with guidelines approved by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. In March 1994, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts endorsed revised guidelines which require departmental annual reports to be tabled in both houses of the parliament by 31 October each year. The amendments to the Public Service Act will require secretaries to furnish their annual reports to ministers no later than 15 October. In turn, ministers will be required to table the reports in each house on or before 31 October each year.

In the event that a secretary considers that the department's annual report cannot be given to the minister by 15 October, the amendments will allow the minister to grant an extension of time. However, if the minister forms the opinion that the report cannot be tabled by 31 October, he or she will be required to advise the parliament before that date of the reasons for the delay and the date by which the report will be tabled. The bill also makes special arrangements for the tabling of annual reports when parliament is not sitting on 31 October in a particular year and a house does not allow papers to be tabled out of session.

These amendments will apply to annual reports for the 1995-96 financial year and subsequent years. However, in keeping with the arrangements which were put in place for the 1993-94 financial year, annual reports of all departments for the 1994-95 financial year have been handled in accordance with the new requirements.

The other amendments to the Public Service Act which the bill contains will facilitate personnel management in the parliamentary departments. Under the present arrangements, many of the powers of the Public Service Commissioner are conferred on the Presiding Officers in relation to the staff of the parliamentary departments. However, the act does not contain any provision which allows the Presiding Officers to delegate those powers to officers in their departments. They may not, for instance, delegate their power to appoint and promote staff, to create and abolish positions and to raise or lower classifications.

This lack of a power to delegate means that the Presiding Officers are required to perform routine personnel management functions which are performed in other departments at relatively junior levels. These amendments would allow the Presiding Officers to delegate any or all of their personnel management powers, except the power to recommend certain matters to Governor-General.

The amendments would also confer on the Presiding Officers powers similar to those enjoyed by secretaries of Commonwealth departments in relation to the cancellation of promotions and the approval of promotions following a joint selection committee process. They would also allow the Merit Protection and Review Agency, which currently has no jurisdiction in relation to the parliamentary departments, to review promotions at or above the senior officer grade C classification.

Finally, honourable members will recall that, following the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure in February 1994, the committee of the whole house was abolished and, consequently, the title of `Deputy Speaker and Chairman of Committees' was changed to `Deputy Speaker'. The Parliamentary Presiding Officers Act currently defines the term `Deputy Presiding Officer' in relation to the House of Representatives to mean `Deputy Speaker and Chairman of Committees'. The bill includes an amendment to correct the reference to the Deputy Speaker's title. The bill also amends the Parliamentary Allowances Act, which is administered by the Minister for Administrative Services, to correct the references to the titles of the Deputy Speaker and Chairman of Committees and Deputy Speaker in that act. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister and Cabinet (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1995 is an omnibus bill which amends four separate acts. As I understand it, these are the Economic Planning Advisory Council Act 1983, the Parliamentary Allowances Act 1952, the Parliamentary Presiding Officers Act 1965 and the Public Service Act 1992. It is a non-controversial bill in all aspects and the coalition will not be opposing it.

PARA.TAB: The first of the main provisions of the bill seeks to amend the Economic Planning Advisory Council Act 1983. The bill abolishes the Economic Planning Advisory Council, known as EPAC, and establishes an Economic Planning Advisory Commission. This follows an announcement by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, on 16 August 1994, that he was establishing a new so-called economic round table to replace EPAC, and that EPAC would be re-established as the Economic Planning Advisory Commission.We are not exactly sure what has happened to this round table or where it disappeared.

EPAC was established as a creature of the former Hawke government. It has, over a number of years, done some good work and it has done some other things about which the coalition has had some reasonable degree of criticism.

However, the government's relationship with the economic community through EPAC and now, supposedly, the commission—like the government's relationship with the ACTU through the accord mechanism—will have some influence in the broader community. The legislation does, I understand, do away with the tripartite consultative process, and the commission will rely more on advice to government.

The second and third acts that are amended by this bill are parliamentary acts: the Parliamentary Allowances Act 1952 and the Parliamentary Presiding Officers Act 1965. The bill makes minor technical amendments to both of these acts, principally to remove gender specific language and to update title references.

The fourth act being amended by the bill is the Public Service Act 1922. The bill amends the Public Service Act to implement the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee of Public Accounts to require departments to report to the parliament by 31 October each year. To enable that reporting to parliament by 31 October, the bill requires that annual reports be presented to ministers by 15 October.

The bill makes arrangements for reporting when parliament is not sitting. It allows the minister to grant exemptions from the deadline, subject to advising the parliament. It also provides for the granting to Presiding Officers of the ability to delegate various personnel and management tasks. The coalition has no problems with those amendments. They seem, at least, sensible.

The presentation of annual reports to parliament is an essential process now that the old system of estimates committees has changed. Much more reliance is now placed on the annual reports of departments and agencies. They have become a crucial, core element of the data and information available to the parliament for the examination of the workings of government. Therefore, the amendment in this bill to the Public Service Act is a very important amendment. The coalition has no objection whatsoever to this bill.

This bill gives me an opportunity, however, to talk about the subject stated in the title of the bill, the Prime Minister and the cabinet. We have a tired Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and an exhausted cabinet, and it seems to me that the process is not really working very well. You would recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, that several years ago our current Prime Minister knifed the former Prime Minister, Mr Robert J. Hawke, and took his job away. This week we had an outstanding example of the former Prime Minister turning around and knifing the current Prime Minister, and taking away from him the spotlight on a major industrial relations dispute which has really socked this nation hard and badly.

The current Prime Minister, the member for Blaxland, comes to his job dishonestly. He had to steal from the Hawke government the prize—the prime ministership—through a whole series of manoeuvres that took several months while the country and the government were destabilised. Then in 1993, on 13 March, we went to the polls for an election to `legitimise' the Keating government. Quite honestly, it seems to me that the man himself took from the people an honest expression of their desire by dishonestly making all sorts of promises which the government has never kept.

When we look down the list of broken promises, we find it is an incredible list. Commitment to no tax increases was junked almost immediately after 13 March with the August budget. There were tax rises in wholesale sales tax, wine tax, petrol excise and tobacco excise, and it goes on and on. We are still paying the increases in wholesale sales tax.

As a result of the budget this year, on 1 July, once again, wholesale sales taxes went up across a huge range of products. The government proposed this year that we were going to tax construction materials, notwithstanding the fact that the housing industry is in one of the worse shapes it has been in for a very long time—it is really on the bottom. And the government proposed to go out and tax building materials. I will say that it is a good thing that this parliament had more sense than the Prime Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Willis), and, of course, the cabinet and the ERC, and rejected that little proposition. But it was a major broken promise. This government said, `No tax increases.' Paul Keating told the people, `Don't vote for this coalition mob because they are going to cost you a general goods and services tax, a broad based consumption tax, and we will keep the faith, we will make sure you don't pay any more taxes.'

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right, and they said we would get tax cuts too.

—That is right; we will get to the tax cuts in a minute. The government broke a very major promise: no tax increases. What happened to the second round of l-a-w tax cuts which were promised—not only promised, but set in legislation? I will tell you what happened: they disappeared off into the never-never, never ever to be seen again. Now we are told that will help pay a dollar for a dollar for employee contributions as part of the government's compulsory superannuation scheme.

PARA.TAB: I do not know whether it will or not, but there are one heck of a lot of people out there, including a lot of independently funded retirees in my electorate, who will never see those tax cuts and who will never see any benefit from those tax cuts. Yet the government, the Prime Minister and the cabinet tell us that people are going to be able to retire without having to resort to the age pension because of the government's compulsory scheme. What they forget to tell us is that it only occurs for people who enter the work force in 2002, and after they have worked 40 years they ought to be able to retire on their superannuation earnings with about the same amount that they would get on the pension—if their union dominated superannuation fund actually produces the goods, comes up with a profit and makes a very reasonable return on its operations.

I will say this: an awful lot of people in this community will never see those tax cuts. A lot of people, quite frankly, will leave us—either leave our shores purposely or die—between now and the time that these so-called tax cuts, which now show up as superannuation contributions only for the work force, ever come into effect.

Another broken promise: commitment to no more budget deficits after the recession we had to have. Remember that one, Mr Deputy Speaker? No more budget deficits. We were promised in this year's budget that in this financial year, 1994-95, the government was going to run at a surplus. That is in great doubt—it is in absolute doubt. There is very little likelihood that the government will meet its projections and manage the surplus. The surplus, of course, after increasing taxes which the government promised not to increase, was really only based on asset sales—that is, privatisation of government owned assets.

In my home state of Victoria, some of my constituents have concerns about state government sale of publicly owned assets, and they write to me about that and they express their concerns. This is really some kind of ideological battle that I do not understand because this federal Labor government has sold just about everything that there is to sell, everything that is not absolutely nailed down. I say to the member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) that there is not much left to sell. The people's bank that would never be sold has gone, has it not? The Commonwealth Bank, the people's bank, privatised, not owned by the government any more!

Now the government is going to sell long-term leases to the airports, it is going to sell the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation and the list goes on and on. By the time we get to government there is not going to be anything left to sell. This Keating government will have sold it all. There is not much of an ideological battle left to fight anymore. It is all gone. It has all gone to finance the budget deficit.

We said we would dispose of some government-held assets for two reasons—firstly, to improve their efficiency and their productivity for the benefit of the people of this country; and, secondly, to retire debt, and to provide funds to buy new, more productive assets that the nation needs to make business enterprises more efficient.

We do need more infrastructure. This government has let our national infrastructure run down. It has run down badly and we need capital spending and capital growth to assist industry to be more effective. But this government does not use asset sales to retire debt, or to finance construction of new infrastructure. It uses them to finance its own spending. As far as I am concerned, that is another broken promise.

This government attacks state governments. It has put the clamps on state government spending and made state governments become more efficient. At the same time this government's own spending has continued to increase at a rate greater than inflation, year after year. This government said there would be no taxes for age pensioners. Remember that one? That one did not just disappear into the never-never, it went under the carpet and down the black hole. I do not think we will see it resurrected in the life of this government.

This government has a very limited life. We do not know when this Prime Minister will have the guts to go to the polls. He wanted to go in September, he wanted to go in December—but he cannot go because he has not got the people behind him. He is frightened to go. When will he go now—March?

We thought it would probably be March, but the Treasurer (Mr Willis) said that the government would dump that important adjustment of parliament's sitting schedule—made by the former Treasurer, Mr Dawkins—which accommodates a budget prior to the beginning of the financial year. The government will dump that commitment. It will have a budget in August this year to give it more flexibility about when we go to the polls. How cynical can you be? Who knows when we will go to the polls? When we do, this mob will not be returned again. There is no question about that.

Another one of those broken promises is matching funding for money raised by charitable institutions during Christmas appeals. That was not delivered. The spending of $113 million to build new gates and common use facilities at Sydney, Melbourne and Coolangatta airports is delayed permanently. Now we are getting ready to sell the airports—if they have the guts to sell them without selling Sydney until its noise problem is fixed up.

The commitment to increase foreign aid by 0.4 per cent of GNP by l995 has been absolutely ignored by the ALP. This mob is the compassionate mob, the social spending mob. They promised for years and years to do something about foreign aid. They have done something with it: they have cut it as a percentage of our gross national product; they have not increased it. We did not cut it. It is this Keating government that has cut foreign aid.

This government refused to build the National Museum of Australia. Remember that one? I remember that one. The government was committed to a national museum, an icon that this nation deserves, but a national museum houses a nation's history and this Prime Minister has reinvented history so many times that the school children are terribly confused about what history is left to this nation. Why would the government fund a national museum, just to further confuse them? Well, it is not going to. That is another broken promise.

Establishment of a single air market between Australia and New Zealand—boy, I remember that one—was a big promise. That was on track until financial considerations seemed to get in the way and all of a sudden we—not New Zealand—pulled the pin. We were all set to go, to deregulate the market, and the Prime Minister pulled the pin.

Next is the commitment on industrial relations. This week we have seen the apogee of the industrial relations debate. What has happened is that even the unions have now abandoned this Prime Minister and have abandoned this cabinet. We are talking today about the Prime Minister and cabinet, a lot of people, an institution which has been abandoned by its close working mates and its funding partners the trade union movement, specifically the ACTU. What did Bill Kelty do? Bill Kelty forgot to talk to his mate Paul Keating, the Prime Minister, and, as a dispute at Weipa between Comalco and 71 of its workers escalated, the ACTU decided to call on national stoppages.

Bill Kelty managed to take out the waterfront workers, he took out the coalminers and he was getting ready to take out the carpenters, the joiners, the plumbers and the electricians, and anybody else that he could get to go out on the streets, in support of 71 people at Weipa who did not want to go on individual employment contracts with Comalco. He took them out and it became pretty nasty, and our reputation as an international supplier was being horrifically damaged. Every 24 hours we lose another $100 million, approximately, and we lose so much reputation that it takes years, if not decades, to make it up in the markets that we need to attract.

We have got a serious current account deficit problem in this country. There are two ways to attack the current account deficit. One, the economists will tell you, is by increasing savings. I am not sure about that but I can tell for sure that one way of attacking the current account is by doing something about trade. Australia is a trading nation. We need to sell more to other people than we buy from them if we want ever to reduce our debt. That means we are highly dependent on trade—trade in and trade out. We do not do our trade very much good when we shut down the wharves and when we shut down the coalmines. Coal is our biggest natural resource export but we closed it down—a shocking state of affairs.

Bill Kelty drew all the lines in the sand and Jennie George said that this is the mother of them all. This will take us back to the turn of the century and before. This will prove the relevance of unions. This proves that the `them and us' debate is still on. This proves that there is class warfare in Australia. This proves that management and their work forces will forever be divided. The unions want to prove that. Why? It is because the union bureaucracy is losing relevance. People are deserting the unions in droves: they are marching with their feet and they are marching with their dollars. As long as they do that, the union movement itself will continue to collapse. It drew the line in the sand but it is damaging the nation badly.

Keating rings his mate Kelty and he has a chat to CRA, and then he has a chat to somebody else. He decides the strike is all over and he goes off to Osaka, saying, `It'll be fixed by noon.' Well, it was not fixed by noon at all. What did Bill Kelty do? He and Jennie George got on the phone, rang Bob Hawke and said, `Come fix this for us, Bob.' So the former Prime Minister, who got knifed in the back by the current Prime Minister—who has now been knifed in the back—came back to solve the big industrial relations dispute.

It has been 25 years since Bob Hawke was last an advocate for the ACTU before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. It was not called that then. It was called the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Remember that? That shows how long ago Bob Hawke appeared before it. The ACTU brought him back just to embarrass the Prime Minister. Boy, is he embarrassed!

He is embarrassed. What did the Prime Minister tell caucus yesterday? I understand that the Prime Minister told caucus that he believed in individual employment contracts. That is what this issue is all about.

The 71 workers at Weipa say they want to be paid just the same as the people who have signed staff contracts and will become members of Comalco staff. They want to be paid the same. I do not know how they can do that with a collective agreement, because the people who sign staff contracts are on staff and are evaluated differently. They are evaluated on their performance. If they do better, they get paid more. If they work harder, they get paid more. If they need to work, they do not get paid overtime—they just work. If they are not needed to work, they do not have to work.

They work together in teams. They decide how to make their jobs more efficient. They decide how to make the trains run on time, use less energy, get there more quickly, move more tonnage, load the ships faster, make sure the ships leave more reliably, and produce a higher quality product which can obtain a price benefit from the client. All of this is doing away with the `them and us' culture that has existed in this country for a century.

It is long past time that we got rid of that culture. The Prime Minister knows it, because, on 21 April 1993, in a speech to the Institute of Company Directors, the Prime Minister said that. What else did the Prime Minister say about culture? He went on Lateline with Kerry O'Brien in 1994. Kerry said to Paul:

SPEECH.PARA: You have got a report coming to you in the next couple of months from a task force which was tasked by your government with measuring the quality of Australian management.
The Prime Minister responded:

Kerry, look, opening this economy up a decade ago has changed the face of Australia including corporate Australia. The first wave of managers went very quickly. The second wave of managers came on, tottered around the scene, and the market cleaned them up. We're into the third wave now and there are some good people there, but we will continue to take time to make this a more sophisticated management scene in this country. But I do believe that there is now a productivity culture out there in business where the good manager spots the opportunity to lift productivity . . .
Got that? He said, `The good manager spots the opportunity to lift productivity'. He continued:

. . . in the business and to split the higher earnings between profits and wages. Now, I think that's on and you can see it in the numbers and you can see it in the inflation rate and you can see it in the growth numbers.

The Prime Minister was talking about culture. We need to change the culture in the workplace. We do not need this class warfare in the culture. We do not need `them and us'. We do not need third parties interposed between those who own and run the business, theoretically, and those who work in the business.

PARA.TAB: I can tell members about the staff contracts that we have been reading about in the newspapers over the last few days. That is what they are: they are staff contracts. I talked to a Comalco worker who said that the thing he liked best about being on a staff contract was the fact he found out what all the goodies were that the staff used to get, because now he gets them too. Everybody gets the same. They all dress the same. They park in the same car park, if they work at the same job location. They all treat each other as human beings—as part of the company and as part of the culture of trying to improve the company's productivity, and the company's profits, so that there is a bigger share for everybody. The company takes some and gives it to its shareholders, and those who work in the company take some. That includes both management and the work force: it is all one and the same, with the staff contracts.

We are talking about culture, and the Prime Minister knows that we need to change the culture. I suspect even Bill Kelty knows we have to change the culture. Jennie George does not know we need to change the culture, because she is still back in a time warp. She is an anachronism who belongs back in the age of the dinosaurs. We do not need that kind of confrontation. What we need is cooperation, and that is what managements are working to try and achieve. They are not all going to make it, and they are not all good managements. But we need to change the culture so that they can make it.

This mob, Prime Minister Keating and his cabinet, are not really doing much to help us get there. Honesty and integrity are part of being in government, are they not? Yet I have just gone through a whole litany of broken promises. Of course, we had sitting on the front bench yesterday and the day before at question time someone who will not be here today, because she is rostered off: the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence), who has been found very recently to be very dramatically wanting in the credibility stakes.

The Prime Minister is not going to sack the Minister for Human Services and Health, because he condones that kind of action. He condones people who do not know how to tell the truth being on his front bench and in his cabinet, so how on earth can we trust anyone in this government again? Do you know what I think? I think the Australian people have really had this mob up to their ears, and I do not think they are going to support another Keating government. When we finally get to the polls, it might be as late as May, because the Prime Minister now will put the election off as long as possible because he knows he has not got a hope in hell of winning—not a single hope. He will put it off and put it off, but the people are not listening any more; they do not believe this government, because it is not credible.

As long as the Prime Minister keeps the Minister for Human Services and Health in that spot on his front bench and in his cabinet, he proves that he has no idea about honesty and integrity. He cannot address the Australian people with an open heart and an open mind and expect them to believe him. There is a litany of broken promises, a flawed front bench, a cabinet which seldom meets and which is dominated, almost entirely, by one man and one man's idea of what should happen in this nation, an idea which is inherently flawed.

The Prime Minister talked to small business people and told them that, if they did not like the current atmosphere, perhaps small business people had better get out. Why? Because this is `as good as it gets'! I will tell you something: the small business survey, which was released yesterday or the day before, indicates very clearly what small business people think of this failed Keating government. That is as good an indicator as it gets of what the Australian public thinks of this Prime Minister and cabinet, and that is not a positive view.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is considering a replacement for the Economic Planning Advisory Council that has, since the election of the Australian Labor Party, advised the government. It was conceived, I believe, by Prime Minister Hawke to be something of an independent sounding board. I remember that, in its first days, there were some concerns being expressed by the Prime Minister and others that EPAC appeared to be too independent. The EPAC reports were even made public on some occasions, for the community to make an assessment of whether or not the economic directions they were setting were in tune with community attitudes. The role of EPAC has changed and gradually it has become more secretive, more prone to be a reflection of government attitudes and less inclined to be an independent beacon for the Australian economy, the government and the businesses and families of Australia. We have now, putting it into a full quango format, a legislative proposal to change the name and revamp EPAC.

PARA.TAB: It is a wonderful occasion for this House to indicate to the government some of the areas that it believes it should set as testing and landmark goals for EPAC. While the business community and the union movement are concentrating on what is called `best practice', I prefer it to be called `world best practice'. The way in which `best practice' is used around Australia now has devalued the term. `Best practice' can mean the best thing we do in our street, the best thing we do in our family or the best thing we do in this place. It is not related to the concept of total quality management, quality assurance or any of the international standards that are measurable standards, where you set yourself a goal and you make a measured assessment of where you need to be and how you are going to get there. `Best practice' is a denigrated term in Australia, and I believe it should be scrapped because it means little, particularly as it is tossed around hither and thither by the union movement. Best practice does need to indicate Australia's relative stance in the world community.

The first thing that the new commission should do is to start to set a few standards: world best practice standards, quality achievements, total quality approaches. It should adopt, for government and government agencies, a process whereby just the very best of world standards will satisfy us so that we can actually measure ourselves against a goal. What the community wants is some way of measuring government performance. When we come to an election, it does not want the process of the group that can denigrate the other the most, or tell the most lies, or appear to be second worst in a contest, to be the standard by which success of government is measured. It wants to have a scorecard, a report card process, where governments can actually be rated against their commitments, be rated against their achievements. Those achievements can then be evaluated against what world standards are, what best practice really does mean, what quality management for government should be aiming to achieve and where the long-term future for Australians and their families rests.

The government has refused to adopt any of these modern management techniques in any of its practices. It will skirt around proposals and come up with agencies like merit protection agencies. It will come up with all sorts of techniques that are a meaningless way of allowing us to continue the slow drift that has been the practice of this government since it came to office.

There is none of the dynamics that Bob Hawke brought to this place left in this government. In fact, in the current industrial dispute, those dynamics—faded somewhat, `lacerated,' the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) says, to some extent—were brought back to play and have produced results. Now there are no dynamics. It is all a matter of managing crises and managing a grey stability that produces no results for the citizens of Australia. I believe the new commission needs to focus on some of the real issues that are worrying Australians and the community, whether it be the union movement, the employers or the families of Australia. I think it needs to set itself a few targets.

I believe that, if the whole resources of the Attorney-General's Department were turned over for three years to unravelling the complexities of our tax act, that would yield multimillion dollar results down the track for Australia. The government has no intention of giving anybody that brief. Michael Duffy used to talk about it as some sort of dream that he had. It would be a wonderful goal to allow an economic commission to try to unravel the processes of taxation and set some real targets for this body that is supposed to be part of the agenda of the Prime Minister.

The fact of the matter is that the government has added heap upon heap, page upon page of complexity to our tax system. The cost of administration is often as much as the tax itself for many small businesses. We have a system where the government does not care about the cost of compliance or collection but only cares about whether it gets its money in. What a wonderful goal to give to a government agency, to turn loose the talents, ability and imagination of competent people in Australia to unravelling and to decomplexifying our tax system.

What about allowing such a commission to look at the unemployment problem—particularly the problem of young unemployed people—and to try to take out some of the factors of confusion, lack of hope and lack of challenge that young people in our cities and country towns face at the moment? There are some answers and there are prospects for young people. Some government programs contribute in some way towards alleviating the difficulties which confront young people, but there has been no national focus. Every now and then a minister jumps up to introduce some smart new program—such as the half-baked program called Working Nation—which has not been thought through. The programs consist of the best ideas collected from here, there and everywhere, half of which do not work and half of which do work.

Why do we not turn an expert or a competent body of some of Australia's brightest people—both in the bureaucracy and in the private sector—loose on a project such as this? But, no, the government will not allow the commission to tackle any large projects such as this. Why do we not turn the commission loose on our overseas debt? Only a few months ago the Prime Minister said, `This is the foreign debt we've got to have. It doesn't really matter all that much, anyway.' The fact that the ratio of our current account deficit to our gross domestic product is the worst in the world does not appear to worry the Prime Minister one iota, one jot, one tittle or one ounce. Australia was with Mexico at the bottom of the pops in 1994. Mexico has improved this year, but Australia remains slinging around at the bottom with a minus five per cent ratio. This ratio was calculated by the OECD by taking the ratio of our current account deficit and comparing it with our gross domestic product.

The government will not focus on the problem, nor will it focus a commission on the problem. The government has not tried to gain answers in any real way so that it can set up a chalkboard goal that we can aim for and so that the Australian community can measure the government's achievements against the government's attempts. I do not think this government would do this sort of thing. This government would rather grope around making day-to-day decisions and being critical of an opposition that it says has no policies.

The only reason the government wants the release of the opposition's policies is so that it can go into the negative mode that it is so good at. The government wants something to criticise. The government wants to pull down because it cannot build up. This government has no proposals for anything positive and it has no vision or hope for Australia. This government would rather destroy. A destructive approach seems to be more in the nature of this government and its Prime Minister than is solving problems and giving challenges to the body that the government is putting into legislative form today.

An economic commission should be doing positive things for Australia, but the government will not give it the goal of wiping out the complexity of our taxation system. The biggest bugbear for our business community is the complexity and the cost of administration of our taxation system. There is the unemployment problem—particularly youth unemployment—but the government will not give the commission this problem. The government will not give the commission the problem of the overseas debt to tackle. The commission is not even to look at the vexed health question. The health area is a very confused area where the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) is under attack for things she has done or has not done and for things she can remember or cannot remember. The minister is an amazing woman for detail when it happens to suit a political point, but she is hopeless if she tries to remember something that should be right in the front of her mind from the time when she was Premier of a state.

Health costs have run away. Australians think that the situation is disastrous and they do not know how they can keep paying for their health needs. One only has to visit the retirees of Australia to understand their pain and anxiety when they look at future health costs, particularly the cost of private health insurance. There has been no effort made to resolve the problem. The minister mucked around with this thing for months and months and then she released some sort of paltry deal-making process between funds and hospitals which does not satisfy anybody and which people do not understand anyway. These problems would be great challenges for an economic body such as the one we have got set up here in this legislation.

I will give the House some of the facts that need to be looked at when we look at things like taxation, employment and overseas debt. For instance, despite the claims that we are not going to move to indirect taxes, when this government came to office in 1983 the personal income tax collection figure was $24.6 billion. This year the figure will be $55.04 billion, which means that the personal income tax collection figure has more than doubled.

If we look at the total tax take over the 12 or 13 years that this government has been in office, we will see that in 1983 the total tax take was $44.9 billion, or almost $45 billion, and the total tax take now is $105.3 billion. There has been a disproportionate increase in those areas of taxation unrelated to personal income tax. Therefore, the greatest proportion of increase for this government—a 240 per cent increase in the total tax grab—has been in the indirect taxation area. Yet this is the government that says, `We are not into indirect taxation.' What more indication could we have that the government's sophistry and its results are two different things? The government makes statements but does not perform. I think most Australians have come to acknowledge the Prime Minister as the master of opposite-talk. If he says unequivocally that he will do something, they know with complete certainty that he will do the opposite. That is the trust—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's even worse if it's law.

—They are very helpful comments that my colleague is making because she is reflecting the attitude of the community. Why cannot we give this commission that is being established today some real goals? There is nothing in the bill about setting goals and visions for Australia. There is nothing about performance and nothing about setting benchmarks for government. There is nothing about giving advice to government, about making public its findings, or about letting us know where the government hopes to be. I think it is time for the Australian people to get the honesty and integrity—they are certainly worried about this in one of the top areas—that they expect in a government. It is detrimental to the nation for the government to go on the way it is, trying to dud the people of Australia.

PARA.TAB: These times have got to finish. If they have to finish with a change of government, so be it, but would it not be better for the nation if this government saw the error of its ways and started to do things with integrity and honesty? The business community and Australian families around this nation have had to change their ways with the collapses that we have had. This has brought a lot of realism into family relationships and into business relationships. People have struggled to keep their house together, they have struggled to maintain jobs. Businesses have struggled to keep going against a huge tidal wave of unemployment and bankruptcy.

This government is a record breaking one with the number of bankruptcies it has created and the unemployment that it has created. It fails to recognise that the errors of the spendthrift ways—the days of Bond, Skase, Laurie Connell and all of that group—are the very errors that it has retained itself. The government refuses to recognise that there is an opportunity for it in this economic area—one of the most important areas of the lot—to set a new agenda.

I was going to make a very political speech about this but I think it is time that we started refusing to be drawn into political comment and started to set some goals for Australia. I am going to refer to some of the advertising that the Australian Labor Party went into at the last election, about the things that it promised it would not do and the things that it has done despite saying it would not. I would like to go into that but I think part of the campaign will revolve around it. We have the opportunity today, with this legislation, with a new commission, with something new and good—

TALK.START.PARA: —There's always been the commission, or EPAC.

—Why do you not turn it into something that we can all accept? You will not give it goals. You will not give it a decent status. You will not give it a decent charter. You will not make it something for all Australians. No, it has to be captive support, bolstering the propaganda of the government. How does that help the nation if you just add to your already massive propaganda machine? The fact of the matter is that, despite what you have said, and what you will continue to say, you will consider new taxes. I will give you an example that is a beauty. There was an advertisement from the last election—and I have a copy here—which said, `Leave our homes alone—no GST on our homes'. Now you guys are considering a tax on building materials. The whole nation knows that, yet that advertisement shows what you said you would not do.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Newell)—Order! I am reluctant to intervene but I would ask the member for Mitchell to bring his remarks back to the bill or relate them directly to the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indeed, because what I have challenged the government to do—and what the minister in his spare time as a member of the government ought to be pushing very hard for—is to give some real teeth to the commission that we are birthing, in a legislative sense, here today. Give it some real teeth, some real challenge and some real goals so that the government's performance, and ours as a parliament, can be measured against those goals. The government will refuse to do that because it would rather have a manipulative political process go on where it can hide the truth, where it can make statements from which it is going to withdraw at the first opportunity and where it can advertise that there are going to be no taxes on the building industry—as the Labor Party did with its advertisement in the last election, saying, `Leave their homes alone,' when now the government is considering taxation on homes.

PARA.TAB: No area is sacrosanct to this government. That is why it is now refusing to give a real charter, a real sense of direction, to this body that we are putting in place today. I think it is a golden opportunity missed. It is a golden chance the government could have taken to really show the parliament that, when it talks about world best practice, a competitive nation and where Australia needs to be in the Pacific or global sense or in the areas of trade deregulation that the Prime Minister claims to be dealing with at the moment, it can demonstrate factually that it is getting results.

What we do not need is the fudging, half-truth denial of things that the government has up its sleeve and for it then to proceed down a pathway of changing the tax system, of not taxing pensioners or taxing pensioners, of giving tax cuts and then taking them away—all of that sophistry that the government has entered into. That is going to be marked against the government at the next election because what the people really want is a bit of integrity.

The government has missed a chance today and I think that is a great shame. Why do not some of the junior ministers start to do something to pull those other blokes into gear? They should be pulled into gear by people who have a sense of direction, an understanding for a nation and a real commitment to our future.
