SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr The Hon D.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The most important provisions of this bill are aimed against police corruption. Members will be aware that the current Royal Commission into the New South Wales Police Service has uncovered distressing instances of corruption and other serious misconduct. Such abuse of power and of the community's trust can never be tolerated in any police service. I particularly regret that serving and former members of the Australian Federal Police have admitted to the royal commission their involvement, with members of the New South Wales Police Service, in corruption and other reprehensible behaviour.

PARA.TAB: The government and the administration of the Australian Federal Police are strongly committed to ensuring that the force is never debilitated by a culture of corruption and misconduct. The institutional culture of a police force is of vital importance to a community. A police force stands at the threshold of the criminal justice system and is in effective control of the enforcement of the criminal law. Each police officer has an extensive authority over all other citizens, coupled with a wide discretion over its exercise. Subsequent stages in the criminal justice process, including courts and prisons, are largely dependent on the activities of police services, and will inevitably be affected by their deficiencies.

The Commonwealth is, of course, particularly dependent on the integrity and efficiency of the Australian Federal Police. Firstly, it is the prime agency for the enforcement of the Commonwealth's criminal laws. In this area, it is the Australian community's first line of professional defence against crime and disorder. In addition, the Australian Federal Police provide a vital link in effective cooperation with international law enforcement bodies. It is essential that the Australian Federal Police maintain the confidence of these bodies, as well as the public's confidence.

In 1989, the government initiated a major and innovative reform of the legislation which governs the Australian Federal Police. The reform was designed, in part, to introduce a new and unique employment scheme which would inhibit the occurrence of the deep patterns of corruption discovered in other police services. One aspect of those reforms was the replacement of tenure with a system of fixed-term appointments. Another aspect was providing the commissioner with chief executive powers in relation to appointments within the Australian Federal Police, including the power to end the appointment of any police member or civilian staff member.

One of the principles underlying this employment scheme is that the commissioner should have a clear and specific responsibility for the integrity and operational efficiency of the Australian Federal Police. Naturally, the scheme also envisages that the commissioner should have the powers and authority necessary to fulfil these responsibilities.

At present, the commissioner's power to terminate the appointment of members or staff members of the Australian Federal Police is subject to only two exclusions. The current legislation states that the commissioner must not make use of this power merely because of an act by a member or staff member where a disciplinary charge has been or could be laid in relation to that act, or merely because a court has found the individual guilty of a criminal offence.

These exceptions were provided in order to separate the Australian Federal Police's disciplinary processes, which can result in dismissal as a penalty for disciplinary offences, from the commissioner's general power to end a person's appointment. In practice, the limitations on the commissioner's dismissal power can lead to situations which are clearly inconsistent with the policy aims of the AFP employment scheme.

For example, it is not clear that the commissioner can terminate the appointment of a member of the Australian Federal Police even if the member admits publicly that he or she is guilty of corruption or other seriously reprehensible behaviour. To dismiss that person from the Australian Federal Police, it might be necessary for the commissioner either to invite the member to resign voluntarily or to initiate disciplinary proceedings. The commissioner's hands could be equally tied if the person were to be convicted of serious criminal offences by a court.

The government believes this situation to be unsatisfactory. Corruption in a police service can seriously undermine the professional self-respect and morale of the decent and honest police who comprise the majority of members. It can also seriously diminish public confidence in the affected police service. Immediate and effective action may be the only way to minimise the harm. On occasions it will not be desirable to wait for lengthy disciplinary or court proceedings to be finally resolved before acting.

Consequently, the bill will remove the present limitations on the commissioner's dismissal powers which relate to disciplinary offences and criminal convictions. The intention is to give the commissioner a broader and more effective power to end an appointment where the commissioner has lost confidence in a person's suitability for the vocation of policing or for continued employment in the Australian Federal Police. The amendment will, in particular, permit the commissioner to act quickly and decisively to end the appointment of a person where the commissioner believes on reasonable grounds that there has been serious corruption, gross abuse of power or serious dereliction of duty.

While the government believes it is necessary in the public interest for the commissioner to have a wide discretion to end appointments, it recognises that the employment rights of individual members and staff members within the Australian Federal Police should also be protected. Currently members and staff members are protected in two ways in the event that they are retired by the commissioner before the end of their term of appointment. First, the person who is retired may seek judicial review by the Federal Court of the commissioner's decision to end their appointment. Second, the retired person is entitled to compensation for the lost part of their appointment.

As this bill will widen the scope of the commissioner's powers to end appointments, the government believes it is also reasonable to extend to members and staff members additional remedies against the possibility that the commissioner's power might be exercised unfairly or unreasonably. Consequently, it has been decided that, in addition to the existing protective measures I have outlined, individual members and staff members who have their appointments terminated early will also have access to the remedies against unlawful termination of employment given to employees in division 3 of part VIA of the Industrial Relations Act 1988. At present the Australian Federal Police is excluded from those unlawful termination provisions by the industrial relations regulations. The relevant regulations will be repealed following the commencement of this bill.

The bill makes one exception to the opening of the unfair dismissal remedies to the Australian Federal Police. It provides that, where a person's appointment has been ended because of their conduct or behaviour, the commissioner may make a declaration that the conduct or behaviour amounts to serious misconduct and that the serious misconduct is having, or is likely to have, a damaging effect on professional self-respect or morale within the Australian Federal Police or on its reputation with the public or with an Australian or overseas government or law enforcement agency. Where a declaration of this kind is made, the person who has been retired will be excluded from the operation of the Industrial Relations Act provisions concerning unlawful dismissal. Such persons, however, will retain the present rights to compensation for their early retirement and to seek judicial review of the commissioner's declaration, as well as the decision to end their appointment.

As I have indicated, the commissioner will be able to make a declaration only where the commissioner believes, on reasonable grounds, that there has been serious misconduct by the person who is retired. Serious misconduct is defined to include corruption, a serious abuse of power, a serious dereliction of duty and any other seriously reprehensible act or behaviour. It is also necessary that the commissioner believe that the serious misconduct is actually damaging, or is likely to damage, the Australian Federal Police in one of the ways I have indicated. This is in line with an agreement between the AFP and the Australian Federal Police Association which provides for the commissioner to exercise this power in cases of serious corruption and gross abuse of power. Further procedures will provide for consultation with the association in the exercise of the power and for me to receive reports annually on the use of such powers.

Clearly these are special circumstances. They are circumstances in which immediate action by the commissioner is needed to maintain the internal integrity or the public reputation of the Australian Federal Police and where it is not appropriate that an outside tribunal should be able to remake the commissioner's decision. The amendment will permit the commissioner to make a declaration either before or after the behaviour or conduct in question becomes widely known. This is to allow the commissioner to act to pre-empt the threatened damage to the morale or reputation of the Australian Federal Police.

The bill also contains several minor amendments concerning two separate matters. One group of amendments is intended to give the Governor-General the power to authorise the commissioner and the deputy commissioners to appoint or promote persons as commissioned officers with the Australian Federal Police. At present the legislation permits the Governor-General to give this authority only to the commissioner. The new arrangements are administratively more convenient. The amendments allow for appropriate safeguards.

The second group of amendments deals with the disciplinary obligations of staff members when granted special leave of absence for service with an industrial association. The effect is to extend the existing provisions which deal with members to staff members as well. The amendments have no financial impact. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) for his second reading address. It gives some clarity to what is a short bill but not necessarily a bill that is easy to understand, particularly when, under the procedures that we now follow, a person does not readily have access to the second reading speech in a printed form when reviewing the bill and explanatory memorandum. At times it is very necessary to look at the detailed provisions and try to understand the nature of the proposals that the government has submitted. The bill is designed to amend the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 and deals with dismissal of Australian Federal Police officers.

PARA.TAB: When passing the Industrial Relations Act the government sought to exempt the Australian Federal Police from unfair dismissal in provisions of that act through a regulation which exempted all contract based employment, being a relatively new initiative in the area of the Australian Federal Police. However, recent interpretations in the courts in relation to these matters have cast doubts on whether this regulation is legally effective in relation to Australian Federal Police employment conditions. It seemed to us, therefore, that the bill was to remedy this unintended situation and, at the same time, to relax the conditions under which the commissioner may dismiss an officer from the Australian Federal Police.

As is often the case with amending bills, the amendments contained in the schedule in item 5 of the bill and provisions relating to dismissal are amended. The purpose of the amendment is stated in the explanatory memorandum as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: This item reflects a concern that subsection 26E(3) of the AFP Act imposes unnecessary limits on the Commissioner's authority over individual appointments thereby affecting the Commissioner's ability to fulfil his or her statutory responsibilities for the AFP's operational efficiency and internal administration.

By way of background, the government did introduce major reforms to the operation of the Federal Police in the 1980s. In the Australian Federal Police Legislation Amendment Act (No. 2) 1989, amongst other things, the tenure of officers was abolished and replaced with fixed term appointments or contracts, as I identified earlier. Under these provisions the commissioner was prevented from ending an appointment merely because of an act or omission for which a disciplinary charge has or could be laid against a person or because a person has been convicted or found guilty by a court of a criminal offence within the meaning of the Australian Federal Police (Disciplinary) Regulations. The effect of this was that the commissioner could not terminate the appointment of a person who had been convicted of corruption or other reprehensible behaviour merely because of that conviction.

PARA.TAB: To dismiss the person, separate disciplinary proceedings would have had to have been instituted. These provisions were set out in sections 26E(2) and 26E(3). The provisions in section 26E(2) provide:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to this Act and the regulations, an appointment under sections 25, 26 and 26B ends:
(a) when the term of appointment ends; or

(b) if, before the end of the term, the Commissioner determines, in writing, that the appointment ends on a day specified in the determination, being a day earlier than the day on which the term ends, but not earlier than the day on which the determination was made—on the specified day.
Subsection (3) was the limiting section. It states:
The Commissioner must not make a determination under subsection (2) merely because:

(a) of an act of omission of the member or staff member concerned in respect of which a charge has been or could be laid against the member or staff member under the Australian Federal Police (Discipline) Regulations; or

(b) a court has convicted the member or staff member of a criminal offence within the meaning of those Regulations, or has found the member or staff member guilty of such an offence without recording a conviction.

The amendment in this bill removes section 26(3). The effect of that amendment is that the commissioner will be able to dismiss a person, irrespective of whether or not their behaviour has been or could be subject to a criminal or disciplinary charge. An officer may be now dismissed without being found guilty. A person whose appointment is ended will be able to appeal against the determination under the unlawful determination provisions of the Industrial Relations Act of 1988 or by judicial review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act of 1977 and through the Federal Court.

PARA.TAB: The next amendment of the bill deals with dismissal for reasons of corruption. Item 6 of the schedule inserts a new section 26F into the bill and it provides that, if a person is retired under 26E(2) because of serious misconduct, the commissioner may make a declaration to that effect. Proposed new section 26F provides that the commissioner must believe on reasonable grounds that the officer's behaviour:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) amounts to serious misconduct by the person; and
(b) is having, or is likely to have, a damaging effect on:
(i) the professional self-respect or morale of some or all of the members or staff members; or
(ii) the reputation of the Australian Federal Police with the public, or with any section of the public, or with an Australian or overseas government or law enforcement agency . . .
In the bill, serious misconduct is defined to include:
(a) corruption, a serious abuse of power, or a serious dereliction of duty; and
(b) any other seriously reprehensible act or behaviour by a person, whether acting, or purporting to act, in the course of his or her duties as a member of staff or not.

The declaration must be made within 24 hours of the determination under section 26E(2) and a copy must be given to the person affected. But most importantly, if a declaration is made of serious misconduct, the dismissal will be excluded from the operation of the unfair dismissal provisions of the Industrial Relations Act of 1988.

PARA.TAB: The net result of these amendments is that there may be potentially three different classes of dismissal under the act. In each case the commissioner will be required to make a written declaration to that effect under section 26E(2).

There will be the situation where a person is dismissed for serious misconduct and the commissioner has made a declaration to that effect under proposed new section 26F. In that case, the dismissal will not be subject to unfair dismissal rules. Then there is the situation where a person has been dismissed but there has not been serious misconduct as defined under section 26F. In this situation, a declaration is not made and the dismissal will be subject to the unfair dismissal rules.

Potentially, there is a third class of dismissal. There may be a situation where a person is dismissed for serious misconduct and yet the commissioner does not make a declaration to that effect under 26F. This separate class exists because the legislation provides that under section 26F the commissioner may—I emphasise `may'—make a declaration of serious misconduct. In these circumstances, the dismissal will not be subject to unfair dismissal provisions.

The bill also contains minor amendments. The first item deals with the minister's power to appoint an acting deputy commissioner if the position is vacant. The second item provides for delegation of the commissioner's or deputy commissioner's disciplinary powers to staff members when the commissioner or the deputy commissioner is absent. Items 3 and 4 deal with the power of the Governor-General to authorise deputy commissioners as well as commissioners to make appointments or promotions by the commission.

The changes to the act will provide that a federal police officer may be dismissed without actual proof of guilt, without separate disciplinary proceedings being instituted. For a dismissal, the commissioner needs only to believe on reasonable grounds that there has been misconduct. However, the position of a dismissed officer is largely protected by the fact that there are appeal mechanisms in place. Where there has not been a declaration of serious misconduct, the person who is dismissed may challenge the decision through the industrial relations system or through judicial review.

It is also worth noting that the employment contract under which the Australian Federal Police are employed provides for compensation for dismissal. Where the dismissed officer is facing charges, compensation moneys are withheld until the charges are decided. Compensation is not paid if the officer is found guilty of corruption or other charges.

Prior to the drafting of the bill an agreement was reached among the Australian Federal Police, the police association and the ACTU in relation to the power of the Australian Federal Police to dismiss officers. The Australian Federal Police Association does not believe that the bill accurately reflects that agreement in that proposed new section 26F should apply only to gross misconduct and not just serious misconduct. It is difficult to see the practical differences between gross and serious, but that is a matter that the association has raised. It is also concerned about the lack of easily accessible appeal procedures. As the bill removes unfair dismissal provisions in relation to dismissal for serious misconduct, a person is able to appeal only through the Federal Court.

The Australian Federal Police Association is concerned about the increased potential for a commissioner to abuse his position with the introduction of more flexible and more expansive dismissal provisions. Its concern is framed in the light of the finding of the Fitzgerald royal commission that the commissioner of the Queensland police was himself corrupt. However, such concerns must be considered in the light of the benefits that this legislation bestows.

The coalition will be supporting the bill on the basis that it is essential that commissioners be given maximum flexibility to fight corruption. It is vital that commissioners be in a position to be able to dismiss corrupt officers effectively and swiftly. This is, unfortunately, needed, as it has been demonstrated by the Wood commission in New South Wales that corruption does exist and it is known to exist also in the Federal Police. This is not to say that all or a majority of police are corrupt, but it is important that all elements of corruption are dealt with.

The New South Wales royal commission this year has uncovered extensive and systematic corruption in the New South Wales police force and, as part of the process of uncovering corruption in that force, members of the Australian Federal Police have been implicated. According to reports in the Canberra Times, at least 10 Australian Federal Police officers, implicated in the royal commission, have admitted to corruption and have resigned. In the Sydney Morning Herald we read similar comments:

SPEECH.PARA: In the past few weeks, six serving AFP officers, including senior officers up to the rank of superintendent, have been forced to resign after `rolling over' to the royal commission and admitting corruption. A further eight former officers have been adversely named or have rolled to the commission.

PARA.TAB: The commission has a charter to investigate corruption in the NSW Police Service but during its investigations into the Joint Drug Task Force, staffed by Federal and State officers, it has uncovered serious corruption by AFP officers.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Justice, in a speech which he made at the opening of new premises on the Gold Coast for the Australian Federal Police—I note that he made it in the electorate of my colleague the member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan)—had some things to say in relation particularly to the Yakuza. I know that my colleague takes an interest in that body because of the serious threat that it poses to law enforcement.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Gold Coast has some very effective members of parliament.

—They certainly do have very effective members of parliament, and the term `liberal' does apply in respect of some. I note that in his speech the minister said that he was concerned about corruption issues. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Naturally I am . . . disappointed that some former AFP officers have behaved corruptly.

He said that he hoped for a clean force. He made the observation that no minister should ever claim that there is no corruption. I suspect that, were he to do so, he would obviously be soon caught out. He made the point that it would be naive—and he said that he is not that—and he said that he is not complacent on the issue.

PARA.TAB: My comments, however, in relation to this matter, I suppose, stem from the fuller report that I have seen on these matters contained in the issues paper that has been distributed by the Australian Law Reform Commission. That issues paper, Under the spotlight—complaints against the AFP and the NCA, in actually outlining why the Law Reform Commission was not going to be looking into these matters, did give, I think, for the first time I have seen it, some fuller statement as to what has been happening in the New South Wales royal commission. It said in paragraph 5.8:

SPEECH.PARA: The New South Wales Royal Commission into Police has recently heard evidence about a number of former and current AFP members being involved in corruption. Ten of the first 16 police officers who have thus far admitted corruption and given information to the Royal Commission are current or former AFP officers and were members of the now disbanded joint Commonwealth-State drug task force.
It goes on to say:

There was also evidence given of corruption in the now disbanded Federal Narcotics Bureau. A current AFP superintendent, codenamed JTF 14, has admitted to improperly planting a knife at the scene of an arrest some 12 years ago. JTF 16, another AFP officer, has admitted to receiving $60,000 for leaking information on AFP operations and investigations.
It then goes on to say:

The NSW Royal Commission has made no formal findings on any of these matters including the extent of any AFP members' involvement in corruption or on the general issue of corruption within the AFP. In these circumstances this inquiry has determined not to attempt to draw any conclusions from the Royal Commission investigation until relevant formal findings are published. However, the Commission welcomes general comments on these issues and other relevant issues arising from the Royal Commission.

That is the first statement that I have seen about the nature and extent—I may not have followed the reporting closely enough—of Australian Federal Police involvement, and, while it refers to former AFP officers, it does refer to current Australian Federal Police officers. I note that the Minister for Justice in his speech said:

I particularly regret that serving and former members of the Australian Federal Police have admitted to the Royal Commission their involvement, with members of the New South Wales Police Service, in corruption and other reprehensible behaviour.

Presumably there are some officers in the Australian Federal Police to which these provisions may need to extend but, given the nature of the discussion in these debates, I wish to simply note that one issue that was raised in the Law Reform Commission report which gave concern to me was, in any disciplinary proceedings, the extent to which it might be possible for people to resign from the force voluntarily in advance of corruption issues being dealt with, thereby avoiding the consequences that might flow as a result of their corrupt activity.

PARA.TAB: The minister, in his second reading speech, did mention that where there is a termination of employment there may still be some action against members arising from the terms of their contract. I would certainly like the minister's assurance that there will be in relation to these particular amendments, which do not deal with the question of voluntary termination, sufficient protection of the public interest to ensure that nobody escapes, fully or partially, the consequences of their actions if they have been corrupt.

It is an important issue. There has been relatively little comment at a federal level about these issues, presumably because at this stage the royal commission has not concluded its examination in New South Wales. There have not been findings by that commission, but potentially these matters do have quite significant implications for the Australian Federal Police.

If we are amending legislation to ensure that the commissioner has appropriate authority in these matters, I would certainly value the minister's assurance that there are not other issues which ought to be addressed in legislation of this sort but which we fail to address at this time, particularly in relation to voluntary resignations.

I noticed that recently, in New South Wales, Superintendent Lysaught—I may not have the officer's title correct—attempted to resign but his resignation was not accepted by the police board in New South Wales. I would certainly like to know if there is a capacity to decline to accept resignations at a Commonwealth level and, if any of those who are mentioned in the royal commission are seeking to quit the service, that appropriate steps are taken to ensure that they are not able to do so if that is going to give them some particular advantage.

I mention finally the issues paper of the Australian Law Reform Commission. The Australian Law Reform Commission has been looking at the issue of shortcomings in relation to, particularly, the complaints system. The fact that it is looking at these issues, particularly when complaints might be linked to corruption, is a matter that makes the issues raised in the paper by the Australian Law Reform Commission more germane. The commission has been asked to report on the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981 and the complaints and disciplinary system in its entirety. It received that reference in March of this year; a final report is expected by June next year.

The terms of reference which it has to look at are to consider and report on the legislation and instructions relating to complaints and disciplinary action; whether the act meets the expectation of the public in terms of police accountability and effectiveness and efficiency; the appropriate standards for handling complaints against police; use of mediation and conciliation to deal with minor complaints; the appropriateness of sanctions provided for in the legislation; and what amendments should be made to the legislation.

It is obviously important that these issues are addressed but also I seek the minister's assurance that this inquiry will not be used in any way as a shield if other matters that relate to complaints about corruption, in particular, arise and there is a requirement to take more prompt action. I certainly would not like a situation to arise where the fact that there is such a Law Reform Commission inquiry leads people to believe that important issues of corruption can be left unaddressed because we are awaiting further advice as to manner and form.

Save those particular comments about the issues of corruption which seem to have given rise to the need for greater flexibility, let me just indicate once more that the opposition is not opposing the legislation. The commissioner will have his remedy, and the government its legislation, and we will afford the legislation as prompt a passage as is reasonably possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to preface my remarks by saying that I believe that most police officers at federal level, as well as in Queensland and indeed in the other states, are honest. They endeavour to do their job to the best of their ability. The reports that we have read of instances of corruption impact adversely on the ability of all honest police—the overwhelming majority of police at state and federal level—to discharge their duties to the community. Whenever we find reports such as those delivered by the Fitzgerald inquiry in Queensland or the continuing revelations from the Wood royal commission in New South Wales, it is increasingly difficult for police officers to carry out their duties.

PARA.TAB: In Queensland, during the Fitzgerald inquiry, when police were endeavouring to go about their ordinary duties as police officers—whether apprehending speeding motorists, investigating domestic affairs or investigating crime—on many occasions the people to whom these police spoke said to them, `You are corrupt; we do not trust you.' This is why it is very important to adopt what the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) is suggesting in the Australian Federal Police Amendment Bill—that we should be creating a culture in the police force which is hostile to corruption. In this matter the minister enjoys the support of the coalition.

This is one of those issues where, as members of parliament, we do have a responsibility to the Australian people, to ensure that the legislation relating to police administration is appropriate and conducive to creating the kind of culture against corruption that we need in Australia.

Most of us were dismayed by the revelations from the recent Wood royal commission, which implicated not only police officers in New South Wales, but also a large number of members of the Australian Federal Police. It was clear that the dismissals provisions in the Australian Federal Police Act were not adequate. The commissioner was inhibited from acting against police officers who were strongly suspected of being guilty.

At that time the only way the commissioner was able to dismiss officers was when those officers had been found guilty of misconduct. Obviously any officer who was found guilty of misconduct should be sacked, and certainly should not be left on the public payroll. But quite often there are very many officers who might well be guilty. If there is very strong evidence of their being guilty, and the commissioner has reasonable grounds to believe that they are guilty, it is right that the commissioner should be able to act against those police officers prior to their actually being found guilty.

There are safeguards in the legislation. If a police officer is dismissed, and in due course is not found guilty, there would be compensation paid to that officer. What we need to do in this legislation is to achieve a balance. On the one hand, we need to consider the rights of the individual, the right of the police officer to fair treatment, and the right of the police officer not be permanently damaged as a result of smears. On the other hand we have to make sure that the Australian community maintains its confidence in the police system and in the criminal justice system. What the government of the day has to do is to achieve a balance, and the government has sought to do so in this case.

Prior to the drafting of this legislation, there were discussions initiated by the minister. The Australian Federal Police were involved, the Australian Federal Police Association was involved, and also—for some reason—the government's master, the Australian Council of Trade Unions. There was widespread agreement that the commissioner did need powers that he currently does not possess, and that the commissioner should be given the power to dismiss officers, subject to reasonable safeguards.

Those safeguards are set out in the bill that we are currently debating. Regrettably, the Australian Federal Police Association now suggests that the proposed legislation does not accurately represent the agreement reached in those discussions involving the Australian Federal Police, the Australian Federal Police Association and the ACTU. The association says that this legislation is not appropriate, and that the commissioner, while he ought to have powers to dismiss police officers guilty of gross misconduct, ought not to be able dismiss police officers guilty of a lesser standard of misconduct.

The purpose of this bill is to entrench the powers of the commissioner to sack a police officer, or other staff, for corruption or serious misconduct. As has been indicated by the shadow minister, the coalition does not oppose the passage of this bill. This legislation will effectively change the grounds on which a police officer can be dismissed.

As I said before, the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police is currently prevented from dismissing an officer until that officer has been pronounced guilty of misconduct. However, the bill will permit the commissioner to dismiss any officer where he has reasonable grounds to believe the officer is guilty. When evidence is given against that officer in a commission or where evidence has been given to the commissioner that that officer, most probably, is corrupt, the commissioner is able to act and can dismiss that officer, even if charges have not been laid against the particular officer.

Under the existing terms of employment contracts—a dirty word as far as the government is concerned—an officer is paid compensation if dismissed by the AFP for misconduct, but, where corruption or other charges are proven, officers found guilty of such charges clearly are not entitled to compensation and, if an officer is dismissed while facing charges, compensation is quite naturally withheld until the outcome of those charges has been decided upon.

The Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police has endeavoured to come to an arrangement which is satisfactory to the community. Regrettably, at this stage the Australian Federal Police Association is not happy with the legislation. I hope that it will come to be satisfied with it. It is very important that we have cooperation between the commissioner and the police association. One of the problems that the association has had is that it says commissioners themselves are not necessarily untainted by corruption. We have had a situation in Queensland where the then commissioner, Sir Terence Lewis, was found guilty of corruption. I suppose the association is saying, `You have, under the legislation, the commissioner deciding whether someone should be sacked. What happens if the commissioner himself is corrupt?'

No one is suggesting that the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police is corrupt, but the scenario highlighted by the association is possible, although quite unlikely. If we are going to vest chief executive powers in someone, then we ought to be careful about the person in whom these powers are vested. I daresay the government of the day would have to look very closely at the quality of any applicant for the position of Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police. I believe this has been done in this case and I would imagine that following the change of government at the next election we would continue to follow that very prudent procedure.

Some people are concerned that the proposal in the bill might be unfair to police officers who are not found guilty of corruption, but the major problem that we have in society is that, at the present time, we are sustaining a loss of confidence in the police and the criminal justice system and the community is demanding that we, as legislators, redress that problem. We ought to make sure that confidence is restored. I believe the legislation currently before the chamber will go some considerable distance towards making a statement to the Australian people that the parliament will not tolerate corruption in the police forces in any shape or form.

The minister has said that no minister should ever claim that there is not corruption within his or her force. That is a very reasonable statement. No matter how well intentioned ministers are, one can never be absolutely certain that there is no corruption. What one needs to do is to create a climate where there is a culture in the police service which is hostile to corruption. I daresay that governments across the nation are seeking to move in that direction.

Mr Justice Wood has said that, if there is an acceptance among a significant body of police that they can safely and intuitively corrupt others, that is a matter of very great concern and a situation that is totally unacceptable, and that the contrary should be the proposition. He pointed out that the vast majority of police are honest—I said that earlier—and that he had a great deal of confidence in young police in particular. I also endorse the comments made by Mr Justice Wood in this respect. I have met very many fine police officers in the federal service and also in the Queensland service and, clearly, they are doing an excellent job.

Mr Justice Wood has gone on to say that the very best that could happen is that the band of detectives who have lived and developed in the tradition of corruption should get out of the force and do it as quickly as possible. That is all very well but, if one makes such a blanket statement, it could be that certain police officers who have served with great distinction for a very long time might be unfairly roped into the net and be deemed to be unsuitable officers whereas, in fact, they have endeavoured to do the best they can on behalf of the community.

What we ought to do is to support this legislation. I am pleased that every member of the House is indeed backing this particular legislation, which will ensure that extra powers are given to the police commissioner where he is convinced that a particular person is guilty of serious misconduct. One really ought to look at the bill just to see what is intended by `serious misconduct'. As the name suggests, it is behaviour which is of a very substantially concerning nature. Section 26F, which is to be inserted in the legislation, provides as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: "26F(1) If a person is retired under paragraph 26E(2)(b) because of his or her conduct or behaviour and the Commissioner believes, on reasonable grounds, that that conduct or behaviour or any part of it:
(a) amounts to serious misconduct by the person; and
(b) is having, or is likely to have, a damaging effect on:
(i) the professional self-respect or morale of some or all of the members or staff members; or
(ii) the reputation of the Australian Federal Police with the public, or with any section of the public, or with an Australian or overseas government or law enforcement agency;
the Commissioner may make a declaration to that effect.
"(2) A declaration must be made as soon as possible, but not later than 24 hours, after the Commissioner makes the determination under paragraph 26E(2)(b).
"(5) In this section:
serious misconduct includes:
(a) corruption, a serious abuse of power, or serious dereliction of duty; and
(b) any other seriously reprehensible act or behaviour by a person, whether acting, or purporting to act, in the course of his or her duties as a member or staff member or not."

So the definition contained in the legislation is a definition which includes conduct of a nature which no-one could defend, and I think it is eminently appropriate that the police commissioner ought to have the power, in these circumstances, to dismiss people who the commissioner believes, on reasonable grounds, are guilty of serious misconduct. We are not talking about very minor conduct; we are talking about serious misconduct. It ought to be noted that there are provisions for appeal to the Federal Court where a police officer believes that his or her dismissal is not fair, and so there are safeguards included in the legislation.

PARA.TAB: Summing up, it is important to recognise that the Australian community is entitled to have confidence in our police services in Australia. I think it is important to recognise that people who are serving officers in the police services of this nation are entitled to fair treatment, are entitled to reasonable treatment and are entitled to be considered as human beings endeavouring to do the right thing by their fellow Australians.

On the other hand, because of the need to ensure that there is confidence in the police service, I believe that this legislation, which gives the AFP commissioner extra powers, is absolutely vital. It is completely unacceptable that we should read that large numbers of federal and other police officers are admitting corruption and yet under the existing legislation the police commissioner is unable to take action against those police officers until such time as they have been found guilty in a court. If there is a situation where a police officer is indeed dismissed pursuant to this legislation and he is subsequently found not to be guilty of corruption, then quite appropriately there are compensation provisions written into the legislation.

I would like to commend the government on the bill which is before the chamber. I think that it is a balance. The police association feels that perhaps the balance is not quite right. The police association feels that the legislation we are debating today does not quite represent the agreement entered into by the Federal Police with the association and also with the ACTU. The minister clearly believes that it does and that the legislation we are currently debating is appropriate, given all of the circumstances.

In the final analysis, I suppose it comes down to a judgment. One has to try and get the appropriate balance. The government and the opposition believe that the appropriate balance has been achieved; the association has some problems at the edges. I am sorry about that, it is regrettable that that has occurred, but I think the interests of the community in this matter should be paramount. The coalition has consulted widely in the Australian community and people have indicated to us that, essentially, they are happy with this legislation.

The continuing revelations, through the New South Wales royal commission, in relation to corruption meant that something had to be done. The minister claims, incidentally, that this legislation has not been caused by the New South Wales royal commission and that this restructure was under way prior to the reports we read in the Sydney Morning Herald and other newspapers about corrupt officers. I do not know whether that is the case or not. But, whether it is the case or not, this legislation is necessary, it is appropriate, and I am very pleased to have the opportunity to support it in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say at the outset that I support the Australian Federal Police in the job they do, albeit with insufficient funds to meet all the responsibilities that they nominally hold. I also want to say that, while the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) made reference when he spoke in this debate to my interest in the Yakuza, I hasten to assure everyone that that is not the subject on which I rise today.

PARA.TAB: My concerns about this legislation arise out of the Fitzgerald royal commission. As the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) said, the opposition is supporting passage of the legislation—although not all members of the opposition are doing so with quite the degree of enthusiasm that he has. The matter of police corruption and how it is to be handled is one fraught with difficulty. All of us would acknowledge that the revelations in the Wood royal commission mean that some action has to be taken in the event that the commission makes a finding that certain Australian Federal Police officers are corrupt.

During the Fitzgerald royal commission in Queensland we had the spectacle of corrupt members resigning from the police force. Indeed, the then Commissioner Lewis himself attempted, as things got warmer for him in the course of that inquiry, to take a type of leave which would have seen him with his full superannuation payout. We had the situation there where certain officers found devices to resign and get their superannuation payouts. There was public outrage about it—and quite properly so. It certainly must not be allowed to happen again.

I acknowledge that this bill attempts to address that matter. But it is not a matter that is going to be specific to the Wood royal commission. It is a law that will be in place for all time, unless parliament at some time in the future sees fit to amend it. I have no quarrel with Commissioner Palmer. I am very anxious to put that on the record. However, we do have to consider all the possibilities. We have evidence that it is possible that corruption within a police force can be run from the top—and that evidence comes from Queensland where Commissioner Lewis was in charge of the major corrupt activities of the Queensland Police Service.

The great horror of the stories that unfolded there was that corruption was institutionalised within the Queensland Police Service because it happened at a senior level. One of the things that emerged, however, was that he was corrupt long before he got to be commissioner. In fact, on the evidence that came out, he should never have been commissioner. It was as he and others rose through the ranks of the police service that corruption became endemic. It did not become any more serious a problem once he was commissioner, except that one would suspect that an awful lot of honest cops would then have been looking for an easy way out of the police force and for other jobs because they would have seen themselves as part of something they just could not stomach any longer.

It seems to me that, in implementing this legislation, the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police is not necessarily going to have personal knowledge on all occasions of all the police to whom this bill might apply. He is going to have to rely heavily on information put before him by his subordinates. We should have a concern not only about the role played in this by the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police but also, or alternatively, by any ranking AFP officer. As I have tried to indicate, it can be senior police—but not necessarily at the most senior level—who can be responsible for institutionalising corruption.

One of the things the Fitzgerald royal commission also revealed was that, when there had been responsible members of that police force who had attempted to do something about corruption, superiors who were corrupt made life absolutely intolerable for them. There was a suggestion that certain police were set up by corrupt officers on charges of corruption. Let me make this clear: honest police were being set up by dishonest police on charges of corruption.

There is one celebrated case which goes on and on in our press in Queensland. I do not know the rights and wrongs of the case. I have no inside information on it but, in a nutshell, it involves a member of the Queensland Police Service who was convicted of the criminal offence of conspiring to murder another police officer. As I have said, this matter has gone on for years and was a quite celebrated case even before the Goss government was elected, so I am talking about something that goes back more than six years.

In fact, Wayne Goss, when he was Leader of the Opposition, promised a pardon for this policewoman. The pardon has never happened. The policewoman has been released from gaol and the conviction has been quashed, because it was established that fabricated evidence was used in her trial. After a very long and noisy public struggle, since the election of the Goss government, she did succeed in getting established an inquiry into the whole matter. However, the inquiry, whilst it did not say she had committed the crime, did not exonerate her and did not recommend a pardon. In the course of the inquiry, she gave evidence that she had been set up by corrupt police, but other police gave evidence that she was the one who was corrupt.

As is every other member of the public who does not know the inside story, I am utterly bemused by the whole endeavour. The policewoman has had her conviction quashed, but she still remains partly condemned because she has not been pardoned. I have not got up to plead her case today, because I do not know the facts that would make it necessary for that to happen. I give that as an instance of how one can get into some very murky water when it comes to the subject of unproven allegations of corruption in the police force.

I note that the defence against this provision in the bill before us today being used improperly is the power which we are now giving to the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, at least nominally, of an appeal to the Federal Court. I, for one, do not see that as a totally satisfactory solution. It is a necessary part of a remedy for injustice, but I do not see it as a total remedy.

If the scenario that I paint were ever to eventuate—where senior corrupt police officers were attempting to set up innocent police officers in order to protect themselves from matters related to their own corruption—the chances are that you would get the result that the honest cops would just get out. They would get out from under, and you would have a wastage of the very people that we need.

There need to be some checks and balances in this, in a way that does not make it too difficult for the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police to act when action needs to be taken, but that simultaneously makes it too difficult for corruption ever to flourish under what purports to be an anti-corruption regime.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Federal Police Amendment Bill 1995 was introduced into the House of Representatives by the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) on 18 October. The purpose of the bill is to allow the Police Commissioner to sack a police officer or staff member in cases of corruption or other serious misconduct. This bill appears to be prompted by the recent revelations of the New South Wales Police royal commission on corruption implicating the Australian Federal Police.

PARA.TAB: The AFP was reported, in October 1995, to be not confirming the number of police who had resigned in connection with the corruption allegations. Later that month, it was reported that the commissioner, Mr Mick Palmer, had requested powers for the instant dismissal of officers, in the context of concerns that corrupt officers could remain on the AFP payroll for up to three years while they sought appeals through the merit review procedures.

The AFP annual report for 1994-95 reveals the results of the activities of the Internal Security and Audit Division of the AFP over the past year. ISAD's primary role is to combat alleged corruption in the AFP. In the last year, the Operations and Intelligence Branch of ISAD investigated 87 references and completed 60 investigations. As a result, 47 of the allegations in those references were substantiated and 59 allegations were not substantiated. ISAD recommended, after completing the 60 references, that 39 criminal charges and five disciplinary charges be laid. ISAD further recommended, in four cases, that fixed-term appointments either not be renewed or be terminated. The division also recommended that seven of what the annual report describes as `other administrative actions' be taken. Two of the 60 references resulted in the laying of serious criminal charges against two AFP investigators. All this is obviously a cause for grave concern.

In addition to ISAD, the Internal Investigations Division of the AFP investigates all complaints and allegations about the actions of AFP members. During 1994-95, the IID recorded 900 complaints about the AFP, made by 596 complainants. During the year, 1,101 complaints about the AFP were finalised by the Ombudsman. Only 70 of those complaints, or 6.4 per cent of the total, were substantiated. None of the substantiated complaints related to criminal activity. The largest categories of substantiated complaints were neglect of duty, misuse of authority, and complaints involving property.

In its present form, the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 empowers the commissioner of police to dismiss an officer by making a written determination that the officer's term of appointment is to come to an end. At present, the commissioner cannot dismiss an officer on the basis of nothing more than that the officer has breached the discipline regulations, or that the officer has been found guilty of a criminal offence within the meaning of those regulations.

Consequently, the commissioner is not able to terminate the appointment of a person who has been convicted of corruption or other similar behaviour merely because of that conviction. The government states, in its explanatory memorandum, that to dismiss that person it is necessary for the commissioner to initiate separate disciplinary proceedings.

Because AFP officers are employed on a contract basis, it was intended that they be outside the unfair dismissals provisions of the federal industrial relations legislation. However, recent court decisions have cast doubt on whether the existing power to dismiss officers is, in fact, outside the unfair dismissals legislation. In addition, dismissed officers may challenge the commissioner's determination, either at common law or under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 on matters of law.

The proposed amendments to the dismissal power will remove the restriction that requires the commissioner to initiate separate disciplinary proceedings. The implication is that, under the amended act, the commissioner may terminate the appointment of an officer irrespective of whether he or she has been convicted of a criminal or disciplinary offence.

The bill would also insert a new section into the Australian Federal Police Act giving the commissioner the express power to make a written declaration that a person's appointment had been terminated for serious misconduct. The section will apply where the commissioner believes, on reasonable grounds, that the officer's behaviour amounts to serious misconduct which is having, or is likely to have, a damaging effect on morale or the public image of the Australian Federal Police.

The bill defines serious misconduct to include corruption, a serious abuse of power, a serious dereliction of duty and other seriously reprehensible behaviour by a person. If the commissioner makes a written declaration of serious misconduct, as provided for by the bill, he must do so within 24 hours of making the determination to dismiss the officer, and must give a copy of the declaration to the dismissed person. If the commissioner makes a declaration of serious misconduct, then the officer who is the subject of that declaration is prevented by the provisions of the bill from having any recourse under the unfair dismissal provisions of the Industrial Relations Act 1988.

The reason for this is stated in the explanatory memorandum to be due to `the special powers and duties entrusted on members of the AFP'. A dismissed officer the subject of a declaration of serious misconduct will still have access to the courts for judicial review of the decision made to terminate his appointment.

There is clearly a need to ensure that corrupt officers are removed from the AFP at the earliest proper opportunity. For this reason, the coalition does not oppose the bill. My personal support of the coalition position is, I must say, somewhat reluctant. I am not satisfied, despite the minister's assurance, that appropriate safeguards to protect innocent individual officers are contained in the bill. I urge further consideration by the minister of the alleged safeguards.

Lest it be misunderstood, I am on the record in relation to telecommunications and interception legislation as believing that corruption of police is one of the most insidious diseases that can affect society, and I do not resile from that at all. I am just a little concerned that there may be an over-reaction to the revelations in the New South Wales police commission, the Wood commission.

The bill ensures that corrupt officers of the category referred to may be dismissed peremptorily and enables the commissioner to dismiss them without reference to the proper dismissal procedures set out under the industrial relations legislation. A basis of the bill is that any concerns about depriving a dismissed officer of recourse under the industrial relations unfair dismissal provisions are balanced by the need to deal expeditiously with corruption and other serious misconduct in the force. But there is a need for parliament to take great care when it contemplates empowering the commissioner to sack an officer on unproven allegations of corruption or other misconduct.

Police officers, more than most citizens, are well aware that in the eyes of the law one is innocent until proven guilty. The proposals in the bill make the AFP commissioner judge, jury and executioner in relation to allegations of serious misconduct made against a member of the AFP. Bearing in mind that it is not uncommon for criminals to attempt to set up police officers, we must be vigilant not to deprive police of rights accorded to other citizens. In my view, the safeguards to protect the rights of officers are not adequate to balance the broad power bestowed on the commissioner.

The bill authorises the commissioner to exercise the power when he or she believes on reasonable grounds that the officer's behaviour amounts to serious misconduct that is damaging to morale. A low standard of proof is involved—certainly lower than the standard of proof `beyond reasonable doubt' necessary for a criminal charge to succeed. What is contemplated is that the commissioner will be satisfied on reasonable grounds, in effect, that an offence has been committed.

It may assist to consider the position of a police officer unjustly suspected of corruption. The commissioner will make a written declaration under the provisions of the bill that the appointment of the officer to the force is terminated before its due expiry because the commissioner believes the officer's conduct amounts to serious misconduct likely to damage the morale and reputation of the force.

To consider the adequacy of the safeguards, it may be appropriate to take a particular example. Assume that several AFP colleagues, themselves involved in criminal activity, a situation to which the member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) has just made reference, have decided to frame an innocent officer who is suspicious of the activities of those officers. They put some narcotics in his locker and stitch up the evidence so that the case for corruption against him is convincing. This gives the commissioner, who is unaware the officer is being framed, reasonable grounds for believing that the officer is guilty of serious misconduct as defined in the bill.

The commissioner, it can be assumed, then carefully makes the prescribed written declaration and follows to the letter the procedure for dismissal. Once the commissioner has made the declaration, the officer finds himself in the position of being presumed guilty and having to prove his innocence. He has lost his job; his career is ruined; and, worst of all, his reputation as a person of honesty and integrity is in tatters. It is essential, in that situation, that the officer have a proper remedy against the dismissal. The factual situation I have set involves corruption within the police, but a similar situation could be set which does not involve corruption within the police. It involves the same sort of thing being done, not by corrupt police officers, but by criminals.

What are the remedies? A number might be suggested. First, under the disciplinary regulations there is no appeal to the Federal Police Disciplinary Tribunal. It might be thought there was a merits review to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Australian Federal Police Act does not make any provision for such an appeal. The officer might contemplate bringing proceedings at common law for breach of contract. He is faced with the position where he has to prove that he is innocent of any wrongdoing and bring a case in a common law court himself. What he has to do is to prove a negative. He does not at that stage even know properly what the case against him is. Short of being able to draft a statement of claim that will withstand a striking-out application, he may not be able to get the action off the ground.

There may be disciplinary charges brought, in which event there may be evidence brought against him, and there may be criminal charges brought, in which case he would have the opportunity of cross-examining those presenting the evidence against him. That would be something of a protection, but those charges may not be brought either before the police tribunal or before a court. If corrupt officers are involved, there may be good reasons found within the force for not bringing such proceedings: they may be regarded as a risk to other operations.

The remedy the minister has particularly relied upon is the proceeding under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. Equally there is an action at common law for similar rights. The proceeding under the judicial review act is a proceeding in which there is a review as to a question of law. It is not a review as to an issue of fact. The only way that the proceeding would be got off the ground by the dismissed framed officer would be if he could demonstrate that the commissioner, in making his decision to terminate and to issue the declaration, had erred in law. He would have to demonstrate either that there was no evidence upon which the commissioner could reasonably act or that the commissioner had acted on irrelevant considerations. In order to do that, he would have to disprove the case against him without at that stage actually knowing what the case against him is.

An application under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act is usually got off the ground by a person affected by a decision of an administrative decision maker by obtaining reasons. There is a statutory requirement under the judicial review act for the decision maker to provide reasons on an appropriate request by a person affected by the decision. In the particular case of a decision to terminate an appointment under section 26E of the Australian Federal Police Act 1979, the right to reasons is excluded. The only point that might save an AD(JR) application for a dismissed framed officer is that there is no exclusion of a right to reasons from the commissioner for the making of the declaration, and that is the only safeguard he has. He is expressly disentitled from getting reasons for the termination but he is entitled to reasons for the declaration being made under this proposed new section. That would mean that the commissioner would be perfectly entitled to give very limited reasons that identify why he regards the termination for conduct or misbehaviour being serious misconduct. It does not oblige him to disclose the reason for termination, but only obliges him to disclose the reason for the making of the declaration.

Having to work his way around that, the applicant is seriously inconvenienced, and he still has the problem that he has to demonstrate an error of law—not an error of fact, an error of law. He has no other means of overcoming the problem. The action at common law for review on the law is hampered to an even greater extent because the action of common law administrative review does not give the officer an entitlement to anything that the AD(JR) Act does not give, and in fact there is no entitlement to reasons in that situation.

Reference is made by the minister to the agreement between the Australian Federal Police Association and commissioner, negotiated I understand with the involvement of the ACTU. The agreement requires the commissioner to consult with the association before terminating an officer's appointment. That is unlikely, in many situations, to be a very satisfactory solution. For a start, there is no guarantee that the officer will be a member of the association, which may not therefore have an interest in pursuing his case. Secondly, in the scenario I painted, other officers may have been involved in setting up the dismissed officer, which might affect the consideration that the association would give to it.

Thirdly, the association itself has no means of undertaking an investigation and may have no means of putting a case to the commissioner on behalf of the dismissed officer. That is the likelihood. In the light of that, any deficiencies in the safeguards in the bill will not be solved by being wallpapered over with an agreement which is neither contained in nor referred to in the act.

There is also an annual reporting requirement: the commissioner is required to report to the minister. This is a valuable monitoring tool but it is at best a general safeguard against improper use of the broad dismissal power and will not affect an individual case.

While we are dealing with deficiency, there is a question arising in the drafting. Section 26F(1) provides that, if a person is retired under section 26E(2)(b) and that has arisen `because of his or her conduct or behaviour,' then the commissioner may make the declaration that has been referred to. The commissioner's power to make the declaration is preconditioned on the dismissal being on account of this conduct or behaviour.

The words in which the conduct or behaviour is defined seem to assume objectively factual conduct and not an allegation of conduct. That may provide a further hurdle to be overcome by the dismissed officer in an AD(JR) application. It may also provide an obstacle to the commissioner, whose power to make a declaration could then be set aside if the alleged conduct on which he relied was not capable of being shown to be objectively factual. But in what forum it would be shown to be objectively factual I am unable to suggest with conviction.

There is a danger that the entire police force will become tarred with the brush of corruption as a result of the disgraceful criminal activities of a very few corrupt police, but in overcoming that problem we do not wish to affect innocent officers. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I will speak briefly in closing this debate. I will take the opportunity at a later stage to give a written response to members who have taken the courtesy to participate in this debate. I should say a couple of things in relation to the speech by the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Williams).

PARA.TAB: It is important to realise that the genesis of this legislation was not a response to the revelations which have emerged from the New South Wales royal commission. Indeed, it was an issue which was raised with me shortly after the appointment of the current commissioner, Mick Palmer, and was taken up in discussions with the AFPA. The agreement that has been referred to predates any of the revelations that have emerged in the royal commission.

The balance that has been struck is not a balance that has been tilted because of some reaction—or overreaction—to those matters. It is in line with the agreement between the commissioner and the AFPA, which provides for the commissioner to exercise these powers in cases of serious corruption and gross abuse of power.

But there is a counterbalance. Currently, in most instances police have no review rights. This legislation provides, in the generality of all matters, that there is now access to the provisions of review in the industrial relations environment. It is a package which balances the legitimate interests of ensuring that instances of major wrongdoing can be addressed swiftly and expeditiously—without having officers against whom there are major allegations, believed to be sustainable by the commissioner, still remaining in the police force, which may be the current situation under some circumstances.

It is also important to realise that there is no support whatsoever for the proposition that there be some external merit review of the commissioner's determinations in these instances. Take that instance that the member for Tangney raised, regarding somebody who has been framed. If the commissioner is unable to see through the matters that have been put to him, how unlikely is it that some member of the AAT, presented with the same evidence from five or six corrupt police setting up another officer, would be able to come to any other conclusion? Merit review in this situation is simply not appropriate.

In these instances there is also a need to make sure that steps are taken quickly to purge police forces of those persons who can be a canker within them. It is a view plainly reflected in the agreement between the association and the commissioner, and it is a view that the public would regard as appropriate.

I emphasise again that it is not an overreaction to the New South Wales matters: the agreement predates them. There are always testy moments in my relationship with the AFPA, as is natural in these situations, but the AFPA has a long involvement in this, and in the main I would only be able to repeat what Mr Justice Wood said of it, that it is seeking to bring about an environment and culture within the AFP which is not conducive to growing any corruption. That is important and I think the public would see it as important. I understand that the opposition supports the bill—notwithstanding what I thought was the most curious speech in support that I have ever heard in my life from the last speaker, the member for Tangney.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Mr Kerr)—by leave—agreed to:
That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 26 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: Will she provide details of all indemnity agreements between the Commonwealth and CSL Ltd, including all terms and conditions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lawrence The Hon C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth has three Contracts under which it provides indemnities to CSL Limited and which are `Commercial-in-Confidence'.
A copy of the `Indemnity Agreement Between the Commonwealth and CSL Limited' dated 23 December 1993 has been provided to the honourable member.
The other two Contracts:
`An Agreement Between the Commonwealth of Australia and CSL Limited' dated 23 December 1993; and
`Diagnostic Products Agreement Between the Commonwealth of Australia and CSL Limited' dated 23 December 1993,

ANSWER.PARA: contain confidentiality clauses requiring CSL's consent before they, or any part of them, can be released. CSL has not given that consent because the Prospectus for the sale of CSL contains relevant information on those indemnities. The Prospectus provides:
`An Agreement Between the Commonwealth of Australia and CSL Limited'

PARA.TAB: When operations of the plasma fractionation facility at Broadmeadows began, CSL and the Commonwealth entered into a contract effective 1 January 1994 and ending on 30 June 2004, and extendable to 30 June 2009 at the option of the Commonwealth. This contract provides for the processing by CSL of Australian-sourced human plasma collected and sent to it by the Blood Transfusion Services.

The contract provides an indemnity by the Commonwealth to CSL against claims by any person who becomes HIV-positive or contracts an AIDS-related condition or hepatitis as a result of the therapeutic use by that person or that person's natural parent or spouse (collectively, a claimant) of a CSL product derived from Australian plasma and produced pursuant to this contract. The indemnity extends to any claim made against CSL by a person who becomes HIV-positive, contracts an AIDS-related condition or hepatitis through infection communicated by a claimant. It extends also to any third party claim made against CSL.

The indemnity covers all Australian-sourced plasma manufactured under the contract for the duration of the contract. However, the indemnity is subject to certain limitations. For instance, the Commonwealth will only indemnify CSL for amounts which CSL is legally liable to pay in respect of any claim. Further, the indemnity will not cover amounts which CSL is liable to pay in respect of a punitive or exemplary component of damages awarded against it. The indemnity also does not cover any liability that attaches to CSL because of the deliberate or reckless failure by CSL to satisfy required standards of care in the manufacture of products.

ANSWER.PARA: `Diagnostic Products Agreement Between the Commonwealth of Australia and CSL Limited'

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth and CSL have entered into a contract which provides for CSL to process and manufacture Australian-derived human red blood cells and plasma collected by the Blood Transfusion Services into certain diagnostic products. The agreement also provides for CSL to supply the finished product free to the Red Cross for distribution.
The contract continues to 30 June 2001, and may be extended for up to 3 years at the option of the Commonwealth.

The contract provides an indemnity by the Commonwealth to CSL covering all diagnostic products produced from 1 January 1994 in terms similar to the indemnity provided in `An Agreement Between the Commonwealth of Australia and CSL Limited'. Apart from the fact that each indemnity refers to its individual products, the main difference between them is that the indemnity in `An Agreement Between the Commonwealth of Australia and CSL Limited' is subject to an additional condition specifically related to the special procedures used in the manufacture of plasma products.
